Комитет ВР и Томенко — против] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304221001/http://rus.newsru.ua/ukraine/04feb2011/ivory_coast.html |date=4 March 2016 }} // NEWSRU.UA от 4 февраля 2011 {{ref-ru}}[http://www.segodnya.ua/world/nashi-mirotvortsy-predotvratili-eckalatsiju-krovavoj-bojni-v-kot-d-ivuare.html Наши миротворцы предотвратили эскалацию кровавой бойни в Кот-д`Ивуаре] // «Сегодня. UA» от 9 июля 2011 {{ref-ru}} |commander1=[[Laurent Gbagbo]] |commander2=[[Alassane Ouattara]]
[[Guillaume Soro]] |commander3=[[Choi Young-jin]] (United Nations) |strength1= Unknown |strength2= Unknown (New Forces) |strength3= 10,000 (United Nations) |casualties1=44–61 security forces killed[http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12478772][http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/12/ivory.coast.violence/index.html?][https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE7190KY20110210][http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/8895648/gbagbo-loyalists-killed-in-ivory-coast-ambush/]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://wordpress.cozen.org/unoci-said-494-people-have-died-by-violence-in-cote-divoire.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120727165828/http://wordpress.cozen.org/unoci-said-494-people-have-died-by-violence-in-cote-divoire.html |archivedate=27 July 2012 |df=dmy }}Government fatalities |casualties2=50+ killed ([[Rally of the Republicans|RDR]])[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700087570/4-killed-in-attack-on-Ivory-Coast-candidate-office.html]{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-12-16/ivory-coast-opposition-says-32-supporters-killed.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230192446/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-12-16/ivory-coast-opposition-says-32-supporters-killed.html |archivedate=30 December 2010 |df=dmy }}[http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/12/ivory.coast.violence/index.html?section=cnn_latest 4 killed in attack on Ivory Coast candidate office | Deseret News][http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/world/12-killed-in-ivory-coast-election-violence-51713.html 4 killed in attack on Ivory Coast candidate office | Deseret News] Opposition fatalities
2 killed ([[Forces Nouvelles de Côte d'Ivoire|FN]])
2 killed,[http://www.lepoint.fr/monde/une-suedoise-de-l-onuci-tuee-par-balle-a-abidjan-01-04-2011-1314170_24.php Une Suédoise de l'Onuci tuée par balle à Abidjan], , ''Le Point''{{cite web|url=http://appablog.wordpress.com/2011/04/01/cote-d%E2%80%99ivoire-deces-d%E2%80%99un-casque-bleu-de-l%E2%80%99onuci-2/ |title=Côte d'Ivoire / Décès d'un casque bleu de l'ONUCI « Database of Press Releases related to Africa – APO-Source |publisher=Appablog.wordpress.com |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011}} 16 wounded ([[United Nations Operation in Côte d'Ivoire|UNOCI]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuDet_-Cote-d-Ivoire.-Chaos-generalise-selon-l-Onu-%5BEn-direct%5D-_39382-1748470_actu.Htm |title=Côte d'Ivoire. Vendredi: un " chaos généralisé " selon l'Onu - Conflits |language=fr |publisher=ouest-france.fr |date= |accessdate=23 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.afreekelection.com/journal/item/3947-article3338.html |title=Côte d'Ivoire - Des jeunes incendient un véhicule civil de l'Onuci et font un blessé |publisher=Afreekelection.com |date= |accessdate=13 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/monde/trois-casques-bleus-blesses-dans-une-embuscade-a-abidjan-12-01-2011-129234_24.php |title=Trois Casques bleus blessés dans une embuscade à Abidjan |work=Le Point |location=France |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}{{cite web|author=Par Europe1.fr avec AFP |url=http://www.europe1.fr/International/Cote-d-Ivoire-un-Casque-bleu-blesse-353939/ |title=Côte d'Ivoire : un Casque bleu blessé |publisher=Europe1 |date=29 December 2010 |accessdate=18 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110128005332/http://www.europe1.fr/International/Cote-d-Ivoire-un-Casque-bleu-blesse-353939/| archivedate= 28 January 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|author=|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g8k5Qk6vKD_Dqr_5U9EdUldhfwow?docId=CNG.57822b8f3ea90a977fd23ac3e2be76ed.3f1 |agency=AFP |title=Abidjan: 3 Casques bleus blessés par les forces pro-Gbagbo, accuse l'Onuci |publisher=Google |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011}} |casualties3=1,000{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11916590 |title=BBC News - Q&A: Ivory Coast crisis |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=13 April 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110422232435/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11916590| archivedate= 22 April 2011 | deadurl= no}}-1,500+{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE73600S20110407?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=UN troops surround Gbagbo's last defenders | Top News | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=7 April 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011}} civilians killed and 100 missing[http://www.wcpo.com/dpp/news/new-proof-of-ivory-coast-vote-killings- New proof of Ivory Coast vote killings] ''AP'' overall, one million civilians fled since disputed election[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12908004 Ivory Coast: Ouattara fighters 'capture Yamoussoukro], BBC News - }} {{Politics of Côte d'Ivoire}} The '''2010–11 Ivorian crisis''' was a political crisis in [[Ivory Coast]] which began after [[Laurent Gbagbo]], the [[List of heads of state of Ivory Coast|President of Ivory Coast]] since 2000, was proclaimed the winner of the [[Ivorian presidential election, 2010|Ivorian election of 2010]], the first election in the country in 10 years. The opposition candidate, [[Alassane Ouattara]], and a number of countries, organisations and leaders worldwide claimed Ouattara had won the election. After months of attempted negotiation and sporadic violence, the crisis entered a decisive stage as Ouattara's forces [[Second Ivorian Civil War|began a military offensive]] in which they quickly gained control of most of the country and besieged key targets in [[Abidjan]], the country's largest city. International organizations have reported numerous human rights violations, and the UN undertook its own military action with the stated objective to protect itself and civilians. A significant step in bringing an end to the crisis occurred on 11 April 2011 upon the capture and arrest of Gbagbo in Abidjan by pro-Ouattara forces backed by French forces.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/UN-Ivory-Coast-Crisis-Not-Over-Yet-119617614.html|title=UN: Ivory Coast Crisis Not Over Yet|publisher=VOA news|date=11 April 2011}} ==Announcement of results and post-election conflict== On 2 December 2010, [[Youssouf Bakayoko]], head of the Ivorian Commission Electorale Indépendante (CEI), announced provisional results showing that Alassane Ouattara had won the [[Ivorian presidential election, 2010|Ivorian election of 2010]] in the second round with 54.1% of the vote, against 45.9% for Laurent Gbagbo; he reported that turnout was 81.09%. Results had been expected and then postponed for days, beyond the deadline, and Bakayoko's appearance to announce the results—at an Abidjan hotel heavily guarded by the UN—took the press by surprise.David Lewis and Loucoumane Coulibaly, [https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE6B13FN20101202 "Ivory Coast's Ouattara wins vote - election chief"], Reuters, 2 December 2010. Bakayoko reportedly chose to announce the results at the hotel, which Ouattara had been using as "his base", because he wanted to have the security of UN protection when doing so.David Lewis and Tim Cocks, [https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE6B10GL20101202?sp=true "Ivory Coast seals borders after opposition win"], Reuters, 2 December 2010. {{Citation needed span|text=According to the 2003 Peace Accords signed in the suburbs of Paris, the majority of the CEI must consist of politicians of the opposition ([[Democratic Party of Côte d'Ivoire – African Democratic Rally]] and [[Rally of the Republicans]]).|date=March 2011}} [[Paul Yao N'Dre]], the President of the [[Constitutional Council (Ivory Coast)|Constitutional Council]] (a body that was viewed by the opposition as favoring Gbagbo, because N'Dre was considered an ally of the President), then took to the airwaves to say that the CEI had no authority left to announce any results, because it had already missed its deadline to announce them, and consequently the results were invalid.Christophe Koffi, [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iedxpbLd4aBzQjdcFHeD-LdVH2qA?docId=CNG.347958328eebaf1a5122e531750726d6.c81 "Ouattara named winner of I. Coast election"], AFP, 2 December 2010. According to N'Dre, the passing of the deadline meant that only the Constitutional Council was "authorised to announce decisions on the contested results." It was widely presumed that the Court would issue a ruling favoring Gbagbo, although the CEI's results indicated that Gbagbo could only be credited with victory if hundreds of thousands of votes were invalidated. At the heart of the dispute lies article 94 of the Constitution of Côte d'Ivoire, which reads:
The Constitutional Council shall control the regularity of the operations of the referendum and proclaims the results. The Council shall decide on: : - the eligibility of the candidates to the presidential and legislative elections; : - the disputes concerning the election of the President of the Republic and of the Deputies. The Constitutional Council shall proclaim the final results of the presidential elections.{{cite web|url=http://abidjan.usembassy.gov/ivoirian_constitution2.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015163707/http://abidjan.usembassy.gov/ivoirian_constitution2.html |archivedate=15 October 2011 |df= }}
Shortly after the announcements, the military sealed the country's borders. ===Double victory claims=== On 3 December, the Constitutional Council declared Gbagbo winner.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11913832|title=Ivory Coast poll overturned: Gbagbo declared winner|publisher=BBC news|date=3 December 2010}} N'Dre announced that the results in seven northern regions were cancelled, and on that basis declaring the outcome narrowly in favor of Gbagbo, who was credited with 51.45% of the vote while Ouattara had 48.55%.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h1lqqW8eecnVcdL82ggEDWQRli0Q?docId=CNG.a5fc0e83efff72426ce88ff122d81b07.751 "Constitutional body names Gbagbo I. Coast election winner"], AFP, 3 December 2010. On the basis of the CEI's results, Ouattara maintained that he was "the elected President" and said that the Constitutional Council had "abused its authority, the whole world knows it, and I am sorry for my country's image".[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11917359 "World leaders back Ouattara as Ivory Coast poll winner"], BBC News, 3 December 2010. He had the clear backing of the international and regional community for his claim to victory, but top officers in the military appeared to stand firmly behind Gbagbo.Tim Cocks and Loucoumane Coulibaly, [https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6B04V920101204 Ivory Coast's Gbagbo sworn in despite poll row], Reuters, 4 December 2010. The [[Forces Nouvelles de Côte d'Ivoire|New Forces]] and Prime Minister [[Guillaume Soro]] both supported Ouattara's claim to victory;Tim Cocks and Loucoumane Coulibaly, [https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE6B309G20101204?sp=true "Ivory Coast's Gbagbo sworn in despite poll row"], Reuters, 4 December 2010. Soro said that he considered Ouattara the rightful President and offered his resignation to Gbagbo on 4 December.Roland Lloyd Parry, [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gjK2yBAXISojkSoJZIWKs4SKJlDA?docId=CNG.eb6f793d7e091dc5315bb6b6cbcea713.c41 "Defiant Gbagbo sworn in as I. Coast president"], AFP, 3 December 2010. Gbagbo was sworn in for another five-year term on 4 December, defiantly declaring: "I will continue to work with all the countries of the world, but I will never give up our sovereignty." Sporadic violence and gunfire were reported in various parts of the country, including Abidjan. Gbagbo appointed a new Prime Minister, [[Gilbert Aké]], on 5 December; Aké, an economist and university president, was already regarded as close to Gbagbo.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gPb3Fl6cGpCbkGUjYIL9H9GuarQA?docId=CNG.468208a520b81057a0741e32037e7230.811 "Côte d'Ivoire: Laurent Gbagbo nomme à son tour son Premier ministre"], AFP, 5 December 2010 {{fr icon}}. Ouattara himself was sworn in separately shortly after, saying that "Ivory Coast is now in good hands". Ouattara then re-appointed Soro as his prime minister.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11920739|title=Thabo Mbeki to mediate in Ivory Coast president crisis|accessdate=5 December 2010|publisher=BBC News|date=5 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101205043235/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11920739| archivedate= 5 December 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===Reactions=== ====Domestic==== There had been rallies from pro-Gbagbo and pro-Ouattara sides. [[Simone Gbagbo]], wife of Laurent Gbagbo, gave a speech in the pro-Gbagbo rally on 15 January 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110116-simone-gbagbo-rally-evangelical-christian-god-sarkozy-devil-ivory-coast |title='God has given us victory', Gbagbo's wife tells rally |publisher=France24 |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011}} Ivorian forces have fired live bullets to disperse protesters. In [[Abobo]], an Abidjan suburb and a stronghold of Ouattara's supporters, there were many violent clashes between security forces and civilians.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE71K01H20110221 |title=Ivorian troops kill protesters, AU team arrives | Top News | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE71J03I20110220 |title=Ivorian troops fire to disperse anti-Gbagbo protest |publisher=Reuters |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} [[Aya Virginie Toure]]{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast women defiant after being targeted by Gbagbo's guns | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/11/ivory-coast-women-defiant/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = 11 March 2011 | work = The Guardian | format = article | accessdate = 11 March 2011 | location=London }}{{dead link|date=April 2011}} organized over 40,000 women{{cite news | title = A plea for help from an Ivorian women's leader amid the violent power struggle | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/p00ff0jq/Outlook_23_03_2011/ | date = 23 March 2011 | work = BBC Radio | format = radio broadcast | accessdate = 23 March 2011}} in peaceful protests that were violently repressed.{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast: women shot dead at anti-Gbagbo rally | url = http://www.euronews.net/2011/03/03/ivory-coast-women-shot-dead-at-anti-gbagbo-rally/ | date = 3 March 2011 | work = Euronews | format = article | accessdate = 3 March 2011}} In an impassioned interview on [[BBC News]], Toure compared the ongoing [[Second Ivorian Civil War]]{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast's well-armed rebels making quick work of revolution | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/01/ivory-coast-new-forces-rebels-revolution | date = 1 April 2011 | work = The Guardian | format = article | accessdate = 1 April 2011 | location=London | first=David | last=Smith| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110413075800/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/01/ivory-coast-new-forces-rebels-revolution| archivedate= 13 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} to the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] and asked for support from the [[international community]]. She called for military intervention to remove Laurent Gbagbo from power the same way [[Charles Taylor (Liberia)|Charles Taylor]] was removed in the [[Second Liberian Civil War]]. ====United Nations==== On 18 December, a United Nations spokesperson said in response to a Gbagbo demand that foreign armed troops leave the country that the UN did not consider Gbagbo to be the president, and that peacekeepers would continue to support and protect both Alassane Ouattara and Ivorian citizens.{{cite web | url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/UN-Spokesman-Gbagbo-Not-Ivory-Coast-President-112131814.html | title=UN Spokesman: Gbagbo Not Ivory Coast President | accessdate=8 January 2010 | date=18 December 2010 | publisher=Voice of America}} On 23 December 2010, the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] passed a resolution that "strongly condemned human rights violations that had taken place in Côte d'Ivoire...that occurred in different parts of Côte d'Ivoire in relation to the conclusion of the 2010 presidential election."{{cite web | url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=10615&LangID=E | title=Special session of Human Rights Council on Côte d'Ivoire concludes after adopting a resolution calling for end to all human rights violations | accessdate=8 January 2011 | date=23 December 2010 | publisher=United Nations Human Rights Council}} The resolution was criticized by [[Amnesty International]] as having insufficiently addressed the situation.{{cite web | url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/news_details.asp?NewsID=19160 | title=Ivory Coast: 'Disappointment' at UN's response to worsening situation | accessdate=8 January 2011 | date=24 December 2010 | publisher=Amnesty International}} ====International==== Angola and Lebanon were the only countries to send their ambassadors to Gbagbo's swearing-in.[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Despite-Growing-Pressure-Ivory-Coast-Incumbent-Gbagbo-Still-Has-Outside-Allies-112528679.html Despite Growing Pressure, Ivory Coast Incumbent Gbagbo Still Has Outside Allies] ''VOA'' The [[African Union]]—which, like the United Nations, formally recognised Ouattara as the duly elected President—warned that the conflicting results and subsequent political crisis could result in "incalculable consequences", and sent former President of South Africa [[Thabo Mbeki]] to mediate the issue. The US, UN, EU, the [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS) and former colonial power France affirmed their support to Ouattara.{{citation|title=Ivory Coast's Gbagbo defies world leaders|date=4 Dec 2010|url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/12/04/ivory-coast-s-gbagbo-defies-world-leaders/|publisher=euronews.com}} On 5 December, former President Thabo Mbeki held separate talks with Gbagbo and Ouattara, acting as a mediator. The African Union had appointed Mbeki to lead an emergency mission to Côte d'Ivoire "to facilitate the rapid and peaceful conclusion of the electoral process and the efforts to find a way out of the crisis."Olivier Monnier and Pauline Bax. "[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-05/thabo-mbeki-arrives-in-ivory-coast-to-mediate-in-presidential-stand-off.html Mbeki in Ivory Coast to Mediate as Gbagbo, Ouattara Each Claim Presidency]." Bloomberg, 5 December 2010. However, he left the next day without a deal.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/africa/2010/12/101207_un-peacekeepers_ivorycoast.shtml AU mediator Thabo Mbeki leaves Ivory Coast without a breakthrough], [[BBC World Service]], 7 December 2010. [[Gabon]]ese opposition leader [[André Mba Obame]] cited the events in Ivory Coast and the international recognition of Ouattara as Ivorian President as inspiration for declaring himself winner of the controversial [[Gabonese presidential election, 2009|2009 Gabonese presidential election]], sparking an ongoing political crisis in Gabon.{{cite news|last=Gualbert |first=Phal |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/27/us-gabon-protest-idUSTRE70Q42C20110127 |title=Gabon police tear gas protesters, tensions rise |publisher=Reuters |date= 27 January 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110207230341/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/27/us-gabon-protest-idUSTRE70Q42C20110127| archivedate= 7 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 28 December, presidents [[Yayi Boni]] of [[Benin]], [[Ernest Bai Koroma]] of [[Sierra Leone]] and [[Pedro Pires]] of [[Cape Verde]] arrived in the country on behalf of ECOWAS, to convince Gbagbo to resign and go into exile for the sake of his country, while declaring it was Gbagbo's last chance before the deployment of military force against him.{{cite news|author=Eric Agnero |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/12/28/ivory.coast.conflict/ |title=African leaders arrive in Ivory Coast to deal with political crisis |publisher=CNN |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=28 December 2010}}{{cite web|author=SME |language=Slovak |url=http://www.sme.sk/c/5697255/prezidenti-skusia-predist-invazii-do-pobrezia-slonoviny.html |title=Prezidenti skúsia predísť invázii do Pobrežia Slonoviny |publisher=SITA |date= |accessdate=26 December 2010}} On 20 December, [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Robert Gibbs]] told a news briefing that it was "time for [Gbagbo] to go" and that "We stand ready to impose targeted sanctions, individually and in concert with our partners around the world, on President Gbagbo, on his immediate family, on those who are associated with him and those who continue to cling to power illegitimately.""[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6BJ4PE20101220 White House: It's time for Gbagbo to go]," Reuters, 20 December 2010. On 21 December, the [[United States Department of State]] announced that it had imposed travel sanctions against Gbagbo and 30 allies. William Fitzgerald, the [[Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs|deputy assistant secretary for African affairs]], said that trade sanctions may be imposed against individuals. On 22 December, State Department spokesman [[Philip J. Crowley]] said that Ouattara's victory was irrefutable and reiterated U.S. demands that Gbagbo step down.Indira A.R. Lakshmanan and Flavia Krause-Jackson, "[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-22/u-s-says-ivory-coast-election-outcome-irrefutable-update1-.html U.S. Urges More Peacekeeping Troops, Sanctions to Stem Ivory Coast Chaos]," Bloomberg, 22 December 2010. ==Threats, violence and human rights violations== Between December 2010 and March 2011, there was a series of sporadic outbreaks of violence between Gbagbo's militias and security forces and Ouattara's supporters, primarily in the city of Abidjan where both sides had large numbers of supporters. On 16 December 2010, clashes between opposition supporters and security forces in Abidjan and [[Yamoussoukro]] left 44 people dead.{{cite web|url=http://www.africanews.com/site/list_message/32393 |title=Two rebel soldiers killed in Ivory Coast |publisher=AfricaNews |date=16 December 2010 |accessdate=31 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329061319/http://www.africanews.com/site/list_message/32393 |archivedate=29 March 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-12-16/ivory-coast-opposition-says-32-supporters-killed.html |title=Ivory Coast Opposition Says 32 Supporters Killed |work=BusinessWeek |date=16 December 2010 |accessdate=31 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230192446/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-12-16/ivory-coast-opposition-says-32-supporters-killed.html |archivedate=30 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/africa/articles/2010/12/16/ivory_coast_march_over_vote_turns_violent_3_dead/ |title=At least 20 killed in Ivory Coast clashes |work=Boston Globe |date= 16 December 2010|accessdate=18 February 2011}} It was alleged that mass grave of opposition supporters had been dug in a pro-Gbagbo neighborhood in Abidjan, but security forces prevented UN investigators from going to the site to check the allegations.[https://www.npr.org/2010/12/30/132496976/u-n-mass-grave-probe-obstructed-in-ivory-coast UN Mass Grave Probe Obstructed In Ivory Coast: NPR] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106065401/http://www.npr.org/2010/12/30/132496976/u-n-mass-grave-probe-obstructed-in-ivory-coast |date=6 January 2011 }} Another mass grave was reported to exist in the village of N'Dotre, guarded by government militias.{{Cite news|author=The Associated Press |url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/12/24/ivory-coast-state-tv.html |title=CBC News - World - Ivory Coast mass grave feared: UN |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=24 December 2010 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} Clashes between rival tribes seen as being pro-Gbagbo and pro-Ouattara killed 33 people in the central Ivorian city of Duékoué 3 January and 6 January 2011.{{cite news|last=Aboa |first=Ange |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7094CZ20110110 |title=Clashes in west Ivory Coast have killed 33: medic |publisher=Reuters |date= 10 January 2011|accessdate=18 February 2011}} Between 11 January and 12 January, 11 more people were killed when fighting broke out in Abidjan between security forces and Ouattara supporters, some of whom were using automatic weapons and [[rocket-propelled grenade]]s, after the police attempted to conduct a raid in a pro-Ouattara district of Abidjan.{{Cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/12/ivory.coast.violence/index.html?section=cnn_latest |title=Police officers killed in Ivory Coast; 3 peacekeepers injured |publisher=CNN |date=12 January 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}{{cite web|last=Aka |first=Evelyne |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/ivory-coast-curfew-after-11-killed-in-abidjan/story-e6frf7jx-1225986910026?from=public_rss |title=Ivory Coast curfew after 11 killed in Abidjan |publisher=Herald Sun |date=13 January 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} The same area was the scene of further clashes on 21–22 February when police again attempted to raid it. 12 opposition supporters were killed when security forces fired machine guns and launched rocket-propelled grenades in the neighbourhood;{{cite web|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/world/12-killed-in-ivory-coast-election-violence-51713.html |title=12 Killed in Ivory Coast Election Violence |work=Epoch Times |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} the next day, opposition fighters ambushed government [[Gendarmerie|gendarmes]] (paramilitary police) and killed 10-15 of them.{{cite web|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/8895648/gbagbo-loyalists-killed-in-ivory-coast-ambush/ |title=Gbagbo loyalists killed in Ivory Coast ambush - Yahoo!7 |publisher=Au.news.yahoo.com |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} {{dead link|date=May 2011}} Gbagbo's supporters carried out a number of attacks during March, attacking foreign businesses and UN offices in Abidjan on 1 March{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/201131175529464635.html |title=Gbagbo youth riot in Cote d'Ivoire - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110308202942/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/201131175529464635.html| archivedate= 8 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} and killing at least six people attending a pro-Ouattara rally in the city.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12637088 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast: Women 'shot during pro-Ouattara march' |publisher=BBC News |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110305030939/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12637088| archivedate= 5 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} The northern suburb of Abobo was attacked by Gbagbo's forces on 13 March in a bid to drive out pro-Ouattara supporters, and mobs were also reported to be roaming the city looking for their opponents and attacking or killing them. The violence resulted in 10 confirmed deaths and scores more wounded.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/03/2011313154729798824.html |title=Deadly clashes in Cote d'Ivoire - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=13 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110314150801/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/03/2011313154729798824.html| archivedate= 14 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} Abobo came under heavy attack on 17 March, killing 30 people, when shells were into a crowded market from a nearby military barracks.{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/03/17/2731772/commandos-attack-ivory-coast-police.html |title=Shelling kills up to 30 in Ivory Coast marketplace |date= |accessdate=17 March 2011}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}} It was unclear whether Gbagbo or Outtara supporters were responsible, though Abobo is generally pro-Ouattara.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12778001 |title=Ivory Coast crisis: 'Deadly shelling' in Abidjan |accessdate=17 March 2011 |date=17 March 2011 |publisher=BBC News Online |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xG97zU4s?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12778001 |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 18 March, the UN issued a statement saying that the shelling was "an act, perpetrated against civilians, [that] could constitute a crime against humanity."{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12787015 |title=Ivory Coast shelling in Abidjan 'a war crime' - UN |accessdate=18 March 2011 |date=18 March 2011 |publisher=BBC News Online |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xHhQFHp2?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12787015 |archivedate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Another 52 people were killed in continuing violence in Abidjan between 21–26 March.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12872920|title=Ivory Coast's Ouattara 'rejects' African Union mediator|date= 27 March 2011|accessdate=26 March 2011|work=BBC News| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110327033930/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12872920| archivedate= 27 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} Opposition figure Guillaume Soro charged that Gbagbo's security forces and Liberian mercenaries had waged a campaign of terror, and that [[death squad]]s had been responsible for 200 deaths, 1,000 people wounded from gunfire, 40 [[Forced disappearance|disappearances]] and 732 arrests. He told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that "women have been beaten, stripped, assaulted and raped. When will the international community realise that a murderous insanity has begun in Ivory Coast?" [[Amnesty International]] said it had received increasing reports of atrocities in the country.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/21/ivory-coast-gbagbo-death-squads-claim|title=Death squads attacking Ivory Coast opposition, claims spokesman|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=21 December 2010|accessdate=23 December 2010|first=David|last=Smith}} By March 2011, an estimated 450,000+ Ivorians had left the country, of which 370,000 were from the capital city of [[Abidjan]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12718544 |title=Ivory Coast crisis: 'Nearly 450,000 refugees' |accessdate=12 March 2011 |date=11 March 2011 |publisher=BBC News Online |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x7RmcoWI?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12718544 |archivedate=12 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 10 March 2011, it was announced that Gbagbo had banned all French and UN aircraft from Ivorian airspace, with exceptions only if the transport ministry approved. The ban was not challenged by the UN, which continued to fly helicopters despite the order; allies of Ouattara said Gbagbo had no legal authority with which to enforce the ban.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12702130 |title=Ivory Coast's Laurent Gbagbo bans UN and French flights |accessdate=12 March 2011 |date=10 March 2011 |publisher=BBC News Online |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x7SA99J5?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12702130 |archivedate=12 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Approximately 1,800 people, including children and [[civil servant]]s, have taken refuge in Abidjan's [[St. Paul's Cathedral, Abidjan|Saint Paul's Cathedral]] since the beginning of the crisis.{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Ivory Coast: Abidjan cathedral provides refuge for hundreds |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13013152 |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher= |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=8 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110410034046/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13013152| archivedate= 10 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} Both pro-Outtara and pro-Gbagbo forces were accused of having participated in the 28–29 March Duékoué massacre, where hundreds of civilians were killed. When asked by U.N. secretary general Ban Ki-moon, Outtara denied the accusation against his force but agreed to conduct an investigation.{{cite news|author=Andrew Harding |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12951990 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast: UN presses Ouattara over Duekoue massacre |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=3 April 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110408055345/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12951990| archivedate= 8 April 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/new-massacre-accusations-for-ivory-coast-20110409-1d8cp.html?skin=text-only |title=New massacre accusations for Ivory Coast |publisher=www.theage.com.au |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011 |location=Melbourne}} ==Peaceful protests== Numerous peaceful protests of [[nonviolent resistance]] have been organized in Ivory Coast and internationally in support of a peaceful resolution to the ongoing crisis. In December 2010, several street protests were held in Abidjan. Hundreds of women joined the protests and banged pots as a warning about the arrival of the militias.{{cite news | title = Country on the edge of CHAOS | url = https://nationalpost.com/news/world/Country+edge+CHAOS/4017648/story.html | date = 23 December 2010 | work = National Post | format = article | accessdate = 23 December 2010}} The protesters were met with heavily armed security forces firing into the crowd and killing civilians.{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast Protests Turn Deadly | url = http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Fighting-Erupts-in-Ivory-Coast-111990569.html | date = 16 December 2010 | work = Voice of America | format = news report | accessdate = 16 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101216152940/http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Fighting-Erupts-in-Ivory-Coast-111990569.html| archivedate= 16 December 2010 | deadurl= no}} In February, 2011, hundreds of youth protested in [[Abobo]], a neighborhood of Abidjan. One man and one woman were killed by security forces who opened fire and used tear gas to disperse the crowd.{{cite news| title = Deaths as Ivory Coast forces open fire on protesters| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12516216 | date = 19 February 2011 | work = BBC News Africa | format = article | accessdate = 19 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110220023936/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12516216| archivedate= 20 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 3 March 2011, 15,000 women held a peaceful protest in Abidjan. Some were dressed in black, some were wearing leaves, and some were naked, all signs of an African [[curse]] directed toward Laurent Gbagbo.{{cite news | title = The Ivory Coast Effect | url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2011/03/the-ivory-coast-effect.html | date = 22 March 2011 | work = The New Yorker | format = article | accessdate = 22 March 2011}} In the neighborhood of Abobo, they were met by security forces with tanks that allegedly opened fire on the women.{{cite news | title = Forces Kill 6 Women Marching in Ivory Coast| url = http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=13045579 | date = 3 March 2011 | work = abc News/International | format = article | accessdate = 3 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110408065608/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=13045579| archivedate= 8 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} Seven women were killed and approximately 100 were wounded. Gbagbo's police officers always denied any involvement of their forces, and Gbagbo's supporters argue that this incident is an elaborate hoax, claiming that the available video footage can hardly match the story. On 8 March, [[International Women's Day]], 45,000 women held peaceful protests across the country. The women were met with youth armed with machetes and automatic weapons firing into the air at [[Koumassi]].{{cite news | title = Ivorian women in anti-Gbagbo march through Abidjan | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/08/uk-ivorycoast-women-idUSLNE72706R20110308 | date = 8 March 2011 | work = Reuters | format = radio broadcast | accessdate = 8 March 2011}} One woman and three men were killed in Abidjan by the army.{{cite news|title=Four dead in Ivory Coast march |url=http://www.pakistannews24.com/2011/03/09/four-dead-in-ivory-coast-march/ |date=9 March 2011 |work=Packistan News 24 |format=article |accessdate=9 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726063523/http://www.pakistannews24.com/2011/03/09/four-dead-in-ivory-coast-march/ |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df= }} ==Outbreak of violent conflict== {{Expand section|date=April 2011}} {{main|Second Ivorian Civil War}} [[File:Ivory Coast March 2011 offensive map.png|right|thumb|Map of the March 2011 Republican Forces offensive]] As the violence continued in Abidjan, heavy fighting broke out in western Côte d'Ivoire at the end of February 2011 as the newly renamed [[Republican Forces of Côte d'Ivoire]] (RFCI) sought to close the border with [[Liberia]], from where Gbagbo was reported to have recruited numerous fighters. A series of western towns fell to the RFCI between 25 February and 21 March as it advanced beyond the ceasefire line from the previous civil war. On 28 March the RFCI launched a country-wide military offensive as Ouattara declared that all peaceful solutions had been "exhausted". After heavy fighting in some central Ivorian towns, the RFCI advanced rapidly across the country to seize towns along the eastern border with Ghana,{{Cite news|title=Key Ivory Coast towns fall as Gbagbo calls for ceasefire |url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/pro-ouattara-forces-seize-another-ivory-coast-town-1 |date=29 March 2011 |publisher=Reuters |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930103518/http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/pro-ouattara-forces-seize-another-ivory-coast-town-1 |archivedate=30 September 2012 |df= }} the political capital [[Yamoussoukro]]{{Cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE72T0NY20110330?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0|title=Pro-Ouattara forces reach Ivorian capital|date=30 March 2011|publisher=Reuters}} and the key port of [[San Pédro, Côte d'Ivoire|San Pédro]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/i-coast-cocoa-town-under-pro-ouattara-forces|title=I. Coast cocoa town under pro-Ouattara forces|publisher=AFP|date=31 March 2011|access-date=1 April 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930215742/http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/i-coast-cocoa-town-under-pro-ouattara-forces|archive-date=30 September 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} By 31 March the RFCI had reached Abidjan as fighting broke out in the city, with Gbagbo loyalists falling back to the area around the presidential palace.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/01/us-ivorycoast-fighting-idUSTRE72S1DR20110401|title=Heavy fighting after Ouattara troops reach Abidjan|date=31 March 2011|publisher=Reuters}} United Nations and French forces joined the fighting on 4 April with helicopter attacks on heavy weapons being used by Gbagbo's forces.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12960308 |title=Ivory Coast: UN forces fire on pro-Gbagbo camp |date=4 April 2011 |publisher=BBC News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xheKjXwC?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12960308 |archivedate=4 April 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Electricity and water to the northern half of the country were also cut 2 March, with no immediate explanation for either event.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12629109 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast: Power and water cut to pro-Ouattara north |publisher=BBC News |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110305030959/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12629109| archivedate= 5 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} ===Status of Gbagbo and Ouattara=== On 18 December 2010, Gbagbo ordered peacekeeping forces from the United Nations and France to leave the country; the government issued a statement saying that it " demands the departure of the [[United Nations Operation in Côte d'Ivoire]] and [[Operation Unicorn]] forces in Ivory Coast and is opposed to any renewal of their mandate."{{cite web|url=http://en.wikinews.org/wiki/UN_convoy_attacked_by_gunman_in_Ivory_Coast_as_peacekeeping_forces_ordered_to_leave_country |title=UN convoy attacked by gunman in Ivory Coast as peacekeeping forces ordered to leave country |accessdate=8 January 2011 |date=18 December 2010 |publisher=Wikinews |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221072502/http://en.wikinews.org/wiki/UN_convoy_attacked_by_gunman_in_Ivory_Coast_as_peacekeeping_forces_ordered_to_leave_country |archivedate=21 December 2010 }} In January 2011, Gbagbo requested a recount of the votes, along with the creation of a committee composed of international members that would oversee the recount.{{cite web | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/indepth/2011-01/07/c_13680942.htm | title=Cote d'Ivoir's Gbagbo goes on diplomatic offensive | accessdate=8 January 2011 | date=7 January 2011 | publisher=Xinhua}} He also engaged in a diplomatic campaign to gain support from countries like [[Zimbabwe]], while at the same time expelling ambassadors from the United Kingdom and [[Canada]], countries that did not recognize his leadership.{{cite web|url=http://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Ivory_Coast_expels_British,_Canadian_ambassadors |title=Ivory Coast expels British, Canadian ambassadors |accessdate=8 January 2011 |date=7 January 2011 |publisher=Wikinews |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110054305/http://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Ivory_Coast_expels_British%2C_Canadian_ambassadors |archivedate=10 January 2011 |df= }} After the election, Gbagbo initially retained control of the country's armed forces and the state media, but in part due to the international sanctions which limited Gbagbo's financing abilities, this control gradually crumbled and the offensive by Ouattara forces caused much of Gbagbo's armed forces to defect.{{Cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0331/In-Ivory-Coast-Gbagbo-s-forces-defect-en-masse-reports|date=31 March 2011|place=Dakar, Senegal|author=Drew Hinshaw|title=In Ivory Coast, Gbagbo's forces defect en masse: reports}} Ouattara was at the first floor of the Golf Hotel in Abidjan while Gbagbo remained at the presidential palace. The hotel was guarded by about 800 UN peacekeepers, who had encircled the site with [[Barbed tape|coiled razor wire]] and guarded the premises with white UN [[armored personnel carrier]]s and security checks for visitors.{{Cite news |author=AP / RUKMINI CALLIMACHI Sunday, 12 December 2010 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2036621,00.html |title=Alassane Ouattara Governs Ivory Coast from Hotel |work=TIME |date=12 December 2010 |accessdate=23 December 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216174313/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2036621,00.html |archive-date=16 December 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} According to local UN mission chief Choi Young-jin, troops loyal to Gbagbo (about 3,000 militiamen according to an Ouattara spokesman{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/212675/ivory-coast-ouattara-camp-urges-force-to-oust-gbagbo |title=Ivory Coast in political violence |publisher=Bangkok Post |date= |accessdate=23 December 2010}}) occupied the neighborhood surrounding the Golf Hotel and set up a [[blockade]] that prevented UN trucks from bringing food, water and medicine to the hotel; UN trucks were sent each day but had been turned back every time. Ouattara had a [[pirate radio]] station inside the hotel that broadcast campaign songs, speeches from Ouattara, and statements by his spokesman. However, technicians working for Gbagbo had [[Radio jamming|jammed the signal]] and so as to change [[Radio frequency|frequencies]] several times a day.{{Cite news|author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/africa-mideast/ivorian-president-elect-confined-to-hotel/article1846161/ |title=Ivorian president-elect confined to hotel |work=The Globe and Mail |date= |accessdate=23 December 2010 |location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101223060247/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/africa-mideast/ivorian-president-elect-confined-to-hotel/article1846161/| archivedate= 23 December 2010 | deadurl= no}} During early March 2011, Ouattara traveled to Ethiopia to meet with an African Union (AU) council tasked with finding a solution to the conflict. Gbagbo refused to attend the meeting, which resulted in the AU confirming Ouattara as the victor in the elections. It was the first time he had left the Golf Hotel since the election was held. ==Reactions== ===Media=== [[Reporters Without Borders]] observed that public media had been neutral in its coverage of the candidates, but it also noted that Gbagbo's campaign had received a substantially larger amount of coverage.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jHzvmwh32nJI6ijIynmTPJrDIGBw?docId=CNG.003c06434b83e46dca5d95fb4df7cf8e.531 "I.Coast presidential challenger seeks to unify opposition"], AFP, 10 November 2010. Reporters have been threatened by armed forces sympathetic to Gbagbo.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/andrewharding/2011/01/gbagbo_loyalist_threats_highli.html|accessdate=6 January 2011|title=BBC - Andrew Harding on Africa: Gbagbo loyalist threats highlight Ivory Coast fears|date=6 January 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110130061058/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/andrewharding/2011/01/gbagbo_loyalist_threats_highli.html| archivedate= 30 January 2011 | deadurl= no}} International radio stations, including [[France 24]], [[BBC]] and [[Radio France Internationale|RFI]], were stopped from broadcasting on 2 March. ===Economy and financial markets=== The West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) recognises Ouattara as the winner of the 2010 election.{{cite web |url=http://www.aip.ci/indexL.php?idl=17833&Kt_Lecture=1 |title=:: Aip:: Agence Ivoirienne De Presse |publisher=Aip.ci |date= |accessdate=18 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228090739/http://www.aip.ci/indexL.php?idl=17833&Kt_Lecture=1 |archive-date=28 February 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The bank of issue of UEMOA is the [[Central Bank of West African States]] (BCEAO)). The governor of BCEAO, Philippe-Henry Dacoury-Tabley, seen as an ally of Gbagbo, was forced to resign by West African leaders on 21 January 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.ladepechedabidjan.net/BCEAO-le-gouverneur-Dacoury-Tabley-demissionne-Le-gvt-Gbagbo-rejette-la-demission-du-chef-de-la-banque-ouest-africaine_a1805.html |title=BCEAO : le gouverneur Dacoury-Tabley démissionne / Le gvt Gbagbo "rejette" la démission du chef de la banque ouest-africaine |publisher=Ladepechedabidjan.net |date= |accessdate=18 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723175125/http://www.ladepechedabidjan.net/BCEAO-le-gouverneur-Dacoury-Tabley-demissionne-Le-gvt-Gbagbo-rejette-la-demission-du-chef-de-la-banque-ouest-africaine_a1805.html |archive-date=23 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12286440 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast: Laurent Gbagbo orders bank branch seizures |publisher=BBC News |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110215001216/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12286440| archivedate= 15 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} Outtara said that the continuing crisis hurts the economy.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-01-19/ivory-coast-crisis-hurting-economy-ouattara-says.html |title=Ivory Coast Crisis Hurting Economy, Ouattara Says |work=Businessweek |date=19 January 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} As a declining economy threatens the status of Côte d'Ivoire, as the largest producer of [[cocoa bean|cocoa]] in the world, a revival hinged on the outcome of the election.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2010/10/20101017183528594852.html |title=Cote d'Ivoire's declining economy - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=17 October 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101201045017/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2010/10/20101017183528594852.html| archivedate= 1 December 2010 | deadurl= no}} The internationally traded price for cocoa and [[white sugar]] fell in the week prior to the election on speculation that the election would spur production.{{cite news|last=Roy |first=Debarati |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-29/cocoa-drops-to-one-week-low-on-ivory-coast-vote-speculation-sugar-slides.html |title=Sugar Jumps to Highest Since February; Coffee Gains; Cocoa Drops |publisher=Bloomberg |date=29 October 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101101205632/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-29/cocoa-drops-to-one-week-low-on-ivory-coast-vote-speculation-sugar-slides.html| archivedate= 1 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} On 24 January 2011, the cocoa price soared following Ouattara's announcement that coffee and cocoa exports would be banned for a month in hope to cut off the funding for Gbagbo.{{cite web|url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20110124-cocoa-price-climbs-after-ouattara-calls-export-ban |title=Cocoa price climbs after Ouattara calls for export ban |publisher=Radio France Internationale |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=24 January 2011}} Ivory Coast was also forced to default on a $2.3 billion bond as a result of the crisis.{{cite news|last=Bax |first=Pauline |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-12/gbagbo-s-capture-may-set-ivory-coast-s-economy-on-long-road-to-recovery.html |title=Capture of Gbagbo May Set Ivory Coast's Economy on Long Road to Recovery |publisher=Bloomberg |date= 12 April 2011|accessdate=23 April 2011}} On 9 February 2011 onwards the [[Bourse des Valeurs d'Abidjan|Abidjan stock exchange]] remained closed after Gbagbo's loyalist forces invaded its offices.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-16/west-africa-exchange-closes-indefinitely-after-gbagbo-seizure.html |title=West Africa Exchange Closes Indefinitely After Gbagbo Seizure |work=Businessweek |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} The following day it reopened.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFJOE71A04Q20110211 |title=WAfrican bourse reopens, was shut by troops: staff | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=11 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} The regional stock exchange [[Bourse Regionale des Valeurs Mobilieres]] moved "temporarily" to [[Bamako]], Mali after Gbagbo's troops attacked its office in Abidjan.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-25/ivory-coast-violence-drives-regional-stock-exchange-to-mali.html |title=Ivory Coast Violence Drives Regional Stock Exchange to Mali |work=Businessweek |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110416153659/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-25/ivory-coast-violence-drives-regional-stock-exchange-to-mali.html| archivedate= 16 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} During the week from 14 to 18 February, four banks{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12478846 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast rush to withdraw bank cash |publisher=BBC News |date=16 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110217173241/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12478846| archivedate= 17 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} had suspended their operations, and Gbagbo in response nationalized them on 17 February.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9LF3DU80.htm |title=Ivory Coast's Gbagbo seizes 4 international banks |work=BusinessWeek |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} Most of the cash machines in Abidjan had been empty or out of service and people rushed to the banks to withdraw their cash.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12478846 |title=BBC News - Ivory Coast rush to withdraw bank cash |publisher=BBC News |date=17 November 2010 |accessdate=18 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110217173241/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12478846| archivedate= 17 February 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE71G00620110217 |title=UPDATE 2-Foreign banks suspend Ivory Coast operations | Agricultural Commodities | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} Reports suggested a cash crisis in the country due to a lack of capital inflows and runs on banks forcing national financial institutions to also deplete their reserves. Several banks ceased operations in the country. The move led to Gbagbo loyalist forces to have "nationalised" those banks and "requisitioned" cash from the Central Bank's Abidjan bureau. The opposition said these actions amounted to robbery.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0223/How-Ivory-Coast-s-Gbabgo-aims-to-solve-his-cash-woes |title=How Ivory Coast's Gbabgo aims to solve his cash woes |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110227090328/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0223/How-Ivory-Coast-s-Gbabgo-aims-to-solve-his-cash-woes| archivedate= 27 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} ===International=== On 23 March, at the [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS) Summit in [[Nigeria]],{{cite news|title=ECOWAS Summit: West African women protest Ivorian situation |url=http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/ecowas-summit:-west-african-women-protest-ivorian-situation-201103246180.html |date=24 March 2011 |work=Afrique en ligne |format=article |accessdate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606164404/http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/ecowas-summit%3A-west-african-women-protest-ivorian-situation-201103246180.html |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df= }} a "One Thousand Women March" was organised by peace activists in West Africa in support of the women in the Ivory Coast. They wore [[Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace|white T-shirts]] and represented countries across West Africa including Côte d'Ivoire, [[Ghana]], [[Liberia]], [[Nigeria]], [[Sierra Leone]] and [[Togo]].{{cite news|title="Thousand Women Protest March" in Solidarity with the Women of Cote d'Ivoire |url=http://www.wipsen-africa.org/wipsen/News/page_3/ |date=23 March 2011 |work=WIPSEN |format=article |accessdate=23 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008014009/http://www.wipsen-africa.org/wipsen/News/page_3/ |archivedate=8 October 2011 |df= }} On 6 April, in [[Canada]] outside the French consulate in [[Montreal]], demonstrators protested against France's military intervention in Ivory Coast and asked for humanitarian corridors to be opened in Abidjan.{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/Local+Ivorians+protest+outside+French+consulate/4565425/story.html |title=Local Ivorians protest outside French consulate |publisher=The Montreal Gazette |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011}} On 8 April, in [[Ireland]] outside the French embassy in [[Dublin]], demonstrators protested against the international community's "military invasion" of Ivory Coast.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0409/1224294302704.html |title=Ivory Coast protest at French embassy |publisher=The Irish Times |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |first=Kitty |last=Holland}} {{Commons category|2010–2011 Ivorian crisis}} ==After the fall of Gbagbo== ===Human rights=== Human rights remained as an issue. In May 2011, Amnesty International reported that both pro-Gbagbo and pro-Ouattara sides had committed [[war crimes]] and [[crimes against humanity]] in the conflict. On 20 July 2011, Ouattara inaugurated a commission to investigate the violation of human rights during the conflict.http://www.francesoir.fr/actualite/international/cote-d-ivoire-chronologie-des-evenements-depuis-mai-2011-129280.html [[Reporters Without Borders]] asked for the release of a detained pro-Gbagbo journalist.http://fr.rsf.org/cote-d-ivoire-mis-en-examen-un-journaliste-de-la-26-07-2011,40699.html The personnel director of the company that published Le Temps, a newspaper close to FPI, was briefly arrested on 24 May 2011 and then released in the same day.http://en.rsf.org/cote-d-ivoire-pro-gbagbo-journalist-murdered-25-05-2011,40345.html The Republican Forces of Côte d'Ivoire occupied the seat of Notre Voie, a newspaper close to FPI, from April to the beginning of September.{{cite web|url=http://www.fratmat.info/component/content/article/51-culture/10523-presse-ivoirienne-les-frci-ont-libere-le-siege-de-qnotre-voieq |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110913012856/http://www.fratmat.info/component/content/article/51-culture/10523-presse-ivoirienne-les-frci-ont-libere-le-siege-de-qnotre-voieq |archivedate=13 September 2011 |df=dmy }} ===Continuance of violence=== According to [[Human Right Watch]], the violence still persisted. Pro-Gbagbo militias had killed at least 220 people during the days immediately before or after the arrest of Gbagbo. In June 2011, it was reported that at least 149 actual or suspected pro-Gbagbo partisans had been killed by the force of Ouattara since April. In August, similar events committed by the force of Ouattara were reported again by the media. A summary of a press conference of UNOCI in August reported several confrontations between FRCI and youths in Ores-Krobou, Abadjin-Kouté, Abadjin-Doumé, Akoupé-Zeudji, and Biéby.http://www.onuci.org/spip.php?article6266 At the night between 24–25 April 2012, Sakré, a village in the Southwest near Liberia was attacked by an armed group equipped with heavy weapons including rockets, leaving 8 deaths.http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20120425-cote-ivoire-attaque-meurtriere-le-sud-ouest-pays ===Politics=== On 1 June 2011, Guillaume Soro formed a new government. No one in the cabinet came from the pro-Gbagbo camp. Guillaume Soro is the prime minister and minister of defence. The mandate of Choi Young-ji ended on 31 August, and Albert Gerard Koenders became the new UN Special Representative for Côte d'Ivoire on 1 September.https://www.un.org/News/fr-press/docs/2011/SGA1303.doc.htm On 28 September, Commission dialogue, vérité et réconciliation (CDVR) (English: Dialogue, Truth, and Reconciliation Commission) was inaugurated in Yamoussoukro. It is an 11-member commission headed by former Prime Minister Charles Konan Banny. The commission includes religious leaders, regional representatives, and Chelsea footballer Didier Drogba to speak for Ivorians living abroad. It is modelled after the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission of South Africa]]. However, Konan Banny expressed that the commission would not have amnesty powers nor powers to absolve anyone.{{cite web|url=http://www.aip.ci/indexL.php?idl%3D21366%26Kt_Lecture%3D1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404234209/http://www.aip.ci/indexL.php?idl=21366&Kt_Lecture=1 |archivedate=4 April 2012 |df=dmy }}{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15086829 | work=BBC News | title=Ivory Coast gets truth and reconciliation commission | date=28 September 2011}}{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE78S01T20110929 | work=Reuters | title=Ivory Coast launches post-conflict quest for truth | date=29 September 2011}} A legislative election was announced in September and held on 11 December. It was the first legislative election since 2000, due to the crisis in 2002. Ouattara hoped that new legislators could be elected before the major development projects announced in the presidential campaign start.http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20110910-cote-ivoire-fixe-legislatives-15-decembre The election was boycotted by FPI, Gbagbo's party, and was won by the parties of Ouattara and his allies. The atmosphere of the election was calm, but the turnout was low.{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/11/world/africa/ivory-coast-elections/ | work=CNN | title=Turnout low in Ivory Coast parliamentary vote - CNN.com | date=11 December 2011}} ===Economy=== On 27 June 2011, UN lifted the last sanctions against Ivorian enterprises, including Radiodiffusion télévision ivoirienne (RTI), Association des producteurs de caoutchouc naturel de Côte d'Ivoire (APROCANCI), and Société de gestion du patrimoine de l'électricité (SOGEPE). On 8 July 2011, IMF resumed the aid to Côte d'Ivoire. On 25 October, the United States announced that Côte d'Ivoire, excluded since 2005, was again eligible for the [[African Growth and Opportunity Act]] (AGOA), which gives trade preferences to eligible countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.aip.ci/indexL.php?idl%3D21991%26Kt_Lecture%3D1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404234336/http://www.aip.ci/indexL.php?idl=21991&Kt_Lecture=1 |archivedate=4 April 2012 |df=dmy }} On 3 August 2012, the first commercial court of Côte d'Ivoire was set up in Abidjan, with the aim of encouraging the investment and the economical development.http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20120804-cote-ivoire-installe-son-premier-tribunal-commerce-abidjan ===Military=== On 3 August 2011, Ouattara promoted several important and controversial ex-chiefs in the New Forces who were said to have brought Ouattara to his position. Among those promoted was Martin Fofié Kouakou, appointed as the new commandant of [[Korhogo]], who had been accused of being involved in extrajuricial executions by UN. ===Gbagbo's capture=== Gbagbo was arrested on 11 April. From April to August, he and his wife, Simone, were under house arrest in separate locations in northern parts of the country. Gbagbo was sent to Korhogo and Simone to [[Odienné]].http://www.francesoir.fr/actualite/international/cote-d-ivoire-simone-gbagbo-est-en-residence-surveillee-dans-nord-ouest-94788.html Gbagbo and his wife were charged with economic crimes in August. The charges included looting, armed robbery and embezzlement. The government, citing its incompetence, has requested the involvement of the International Criminal Court (ICC) in the investigation of violence related crimes.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14581870 | work=BBC News | title=Ivory Coast conflict: Gbagbos face economic charges | date=18 August 2011}} On 3 October, the judges of ICC authorized its prosecutor Luis Moreno-Ocampo to probe post-election war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by forces loyal to both Gbagbo and Ouattara.http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20111129-cpi-lance-mandat-arret-contre-laurent-gbagbo-c%C3%B4te-ivoirehttp://www.france24.com/en/20111129-i-coasts-gbagbo-faces-transfer-war-crimes-court{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} With an arrest warrant issued on 23 November and made known to the public on 29 November, Gbagbo was sent from Côte d'Ivoire on 29 November and arrived in a prison in [[Scheveningen]], a suburb of [[the Hague]], on 30 November.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/01/world/africa/gbagbo-ivory-coast-hague-charges.html | work=The New York Times | first=Marlise | last=Simons | title=Ex-President of Ivory Coast Arrives in the Hague to Face Charges | date=30 November 2011}}http://www.france24.com/fr/20111130-cote-ivoire-laurent-gbagbo-cpi-justice-cour-penale-internationale-procedure-exactions-crimes-contre-humanite-meurtreshttp://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20111201-plusieurs-mois-detention-haye-commencent-laurent-gbagbo ==See also== * [[Impact of 2010–2011 Middle East and North Africa protests]] * [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1980]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite journal |last=Bah |first=Abu Bakarr |year=2010 |title=Democracy and civil war: Citizenship and peacemaking in Côte d'Ivoire |journal=[[African Affairs]] |volume=109 |issue=437 |pages=597–615 |doi=10.1093/afraf/adq046 }} * {{Cite book |authorlink=Paul Collier |last=Collier |first=Paul |chapter=Meltdown in Côte d'Ivoire |year=2010 |title=Wars, Guns, and Votes: Democracy in Dangerous Places |location=New York |publisher=Harper Perennial |isbn=978-0-06-147964-9 |pages=155–168 }} * {{Cite journal |last=Zounmenou |first=David |year=2011 |title=Côte d'Ivoire's post-electoral conflict: what is at stake? |journal=[[African Security Review]] |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=48–55 |doi=10.1080/10246029.2011.561011 }} ==External links== * [http://www.democracynow.org/2010/12/27/horace_campbell_on_ivory_coast_crisis Thousands Flee Ivory Coast as President Gbagbo Refuses to Cede Power] - video report by ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' * [https://www.ictj.org/our-work/regions-and-countries/c%C3%B4te-divoire International Center for Transitional Justice, Côte d'Ivoire] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110125024314/http://ivorycoastelection.org/files/Attachment_J_AU_Observers.pdf Statement of the African Union Observer Mission] {{Côte d'Ivoire topics}}
