Coast]] [[Category:2011 in Ivory Coast]] [[Category:2011 riots|Ivorian crisis]] [[Category:2010 in politics|Ivorian crisis]] [[Category:2011 in politics|Ivorian crisis]]

page.title: A New Partnership Between the Indigenous Peoples and the Government of Taiwan

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=December 2008}} {{Wikisourcelang|zh|原住民族和台灣政府新的夥伴關係|A New Partnership Between the Indigenous Peoples and the Government of Taiwan}}
'''A New Partnership Between the Indigenous Peoples and the Government of Taiwan''' ({{zh|c=原住民族和台灣政府新的夥伴關係|p=Yuán Zhù Mínzú Hé Táiwān Zhèngfǔ Xīn De Huǒbàn Guānxì}}) is a [[treaty]]-like document signed in [[Orchid Island]], [[Taiwan]] on 10 September 1999 by the representatives of the [[Taiwanese aborigines|indigenous peoples of Taiwan]] and the then-presidential candidate [[Chen Shui-bian]] (who went on to win the [[ROC presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential election]] for the [[Democratic Progressive Party]]).
The seven articles in the documents includes: #Recognizing the inherent sovereignty of Taiwan’s Indigenous Peoples #Promoting autonomy for Indigenous Peoples #Concluding a land treaty with Taiwan’s Indigenous Peoples #Reinstating traditional names of Indigenous communities and natural landmarks #Recovering traditional territories of Indigenous communities and Peoples #Recovering use of traditional natural resources and furthering the development of self-determination #Providing legislative (parliamentary) representation for each Indigenous People
The document later became the official indigenous policy for the DPP Government. However, as the document was signed before Shui-bian Chen became the President, the efficacy of the document has been contested.
On 2002-10-19, Chen, as the head of state and government, reaffirmed the new partnership between indigenous nations and the Government of Taiwan in a ceremony with indigenous tribal representatives.
==See also== * [[Taiwanese aborigines]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:New Partnership Between The Indigenous Peoples And The Government Of Taiwan}} [[Category:Taiwanese aboriginal culture and history]] [[Category:Indigenous politics|Taiwan]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1999]] [[Category:Treaties of Taiwan]] [[Category:1999 in Taiwan]]
{{Taiwan-poli-stub}}

{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=December 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:Francis Atterbury after Sir Godfrey Kneller, Bt.jpg|thumb|[[Francis Atterbury]], after [[Godfrey Kneller]] ]] The '''Atterbury Plot''' was a conspiracy led by [[Francis Atterbury]], [[Bishop of Rochester]] and [[Dean of Westminster]], aimed at the restoration of the [[House of Stuart]] to the throne of [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Great Britain]]. It came some years after the unsuccessful [[Jacobite Rising of 1715]], at a time when the [[Whiggism|Whig]] government of the new [[House of Hanover|Hanoverian king]] was deeply unpopular.
Apart from Atterbury, other conspirators included [[Charles Boyle, 4th Earl of Orrery]], [[William North, 6th Baron North|Lord North and Grey]], [[Sir Henry Goring, 4th Baronet|Sir Henry Goring]], [[Christopher Layer]], [[John Plunkett (Jacobite)|John Plunkett]], and [[Seven_Men_of_Moidart#George_Kelly|George Kelly]].
The Plot was later considered the greatest threat to the Hanoverians between the [[Jacobite risings]] of 1715 and 1745.<ref>[http://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/exhibitions/Spies/Atterbury.html Atterbury] at lib.cam.ac.uk, accessed 10 June 2013</ref> It collapsed in 1722, when some of the conspirators were charged with [[treason]]. However, evidence was in short supply, and Atterbury himself escaped with removal from his [[Church of England]] positions and exile.
==Background== Atterbury was a [[Tory]] and a leader of the [[High Church]] party in the [[Church of England]]. In 1710, the prosecution of [[Henry Sacheverell]] led to an explosion of High Church fanaticism, and Atterbury helped Sacheverell with his defence, then became an active pamphleteer against the [[Whiggism|Whig]] ministry. When the ministry changed, rewards came to him. [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]] chose him as her chief adviser in church matters, and in August 1711 she appointed him [[List of Deans of Christ Church, Oxford|Dean]] of [[Christ Church, Oxford]], a strongly Tory college. In 1713 he was promoted to become [[Bishop of Rochester]] and Dean of [[Westminster Abbey]], and if the Tories had remained in power he might have risen much higher, so he dreaded the [[House of Hanover|Hanoverian accession]] planned by the [[Act of Settlement 1701|Act of Settlement]] of 1701. The death of Queen Anne in 1714 was a setback for him. He took the oath of allegiance to [[George I of Great Britain|George I]], but he became an opponent of the new government. He was in indirect communication with the family of the Pretender, and when the [[Jacobite rising of 1715|Jacobite Rising of 1715]] appeared, he refused to sign a declaration in which other bishops attached themselves to the Protestant accession. In 1717 hundreds of Jacobites arrested at the time of the Rising were released from prison by the [[Indemnity Act 1717|Act of Grace and Pardon]], and Atterbury began to correspond directly with [[James Francis Edward Stuart]]. He was later accused of plotting a coup d'état which involved the capture of the Hanoverian royal family and the proclamation of the Pretender as James III.<ref name=dnb>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Atterbury, Francis|volume=2|pages=233–238}}</ref>
Events of 1720, notably the [[Bubble Act]] and the collapse of the [[South Sea Company]], left the pro-Hanoverian Whig government in disarray and deeply unpopular with the many [[ruling class]] investors who had lost heavily. Atterbury seized the moment to conspire with the exiled [[John Erskine, 22nd Earl of Mar]], who [[Jacobite Peerage|at the Jacobite court was]] [[Duke of Mar]], who had been the Pretender's Secretary of State.<ref name=docs>David Bayne Horn, Mary Ransome, eds., ''English Historical Documents: 1714–1783: VII'' (1996), p. 150</ref>
==Plot of 1721== [[File:Christopher Layer engraving.png|thumb|150px|Christopher Layer]] The aim of the conspirators was a new Jacobite rising, to coincide with the [[British general election, 1722|general election expected in 1722]], this date being foreseen because by the [[Septennial Act 1716|Septennial Act]] of 1716 parliament was enabled to sit for seven years after the [[British general election, 1715|election of 1715]].<ref name=docs/>
[[Sir Henry Goring, 4th Baronet|Sir Henry Goring]], who was himself standing (unsuccessfully as turned out) in the election as MP for his old seat of [[Steyning (UK Parliament constituency)|Steyning]] in Sussex, wrote to the Pretender on 20 March 1721 a letter in which he put forward a plan for a restoration of the Stuart monarchy with the assistance of an invasion by Irish exile troops commanded by the [[James Butler, 2nd Duke of Ormonde|Duke of Ormonde]] from Spain and Lieutenant-General Dillon from France.<ref name=hop>[http://www.histparl.ac.uk/volume/1715-1754/member/goring-sir-henry-1679-1731] History of Parliament Online article on Goring by Eveline Cruickshanks.</ref>
[[Christopher Layer]], a [[barrister]] of the [[Middle Temple]] and an agent and legal advisor to the "notorious Jacobite" [[William North, 6th Baron North|Lord North and Grey]],<ref>Ian Higgins, ''Swift's Politics: A Study in Disaffection'' (1994), p. 146</ref> met some fellow plotters regularly at an inn in [[Stratford-le-Bow]], and by the summer of 1721 had succeeded in recruiting some soldiers at [[Romford]] and [[Leytonstone]]. He then travelled to Rome, where he met the Pretender to reveal the details of a plot. Layer stated that he represented a large number of influential Jacobites, who proposed to recruit old soldiers to seize the [[Tower of London]], the [[Bank of England]], the [[Royal Mint]], and other government buildings in [[Westminster]] and the [[City of London]], to capture the Hanoverian royal family, and to kill other key men. English Tories were to summon their men, secure their counties, and march on London, while volunteers from the [[Irish Brigade (France)|Irish Brigade]] of the French Army were to land in England to join them. Layer returned to London with assurances of royal favour from the Pretender.<ref name=dnblayer>{{DNB|wstitle=Layer, Christopher|volume=32}}</ref>
==Collapse== The plot collapsed in England in the spring of 1722, at the time of the death of [[Charles Spencer, 3rd Earl of Sunderland]], who a year before had been forced to resign as [[First Lord of the Treasury]]. He died on 19 April, when the [[Philippe II, Duke of Orléans|Duke of Orleans]], Regent of France, made it known to [[John Carteret, 2nd Earl Granville|Carteret]], [[Robert Walpole]]'s [[Secretary of State for the Southern Department]], that the Jacobites had asked him to send three thousand men in support of a coup d'état to take place early in May. The French said they had refused permission for the [[James Butler, 2nd Duke of Ormonde|Duke of Ormonde]] to march a force across France to a channel port and they had also moved their Irish Brigade away from [[Dunkirk]].<ref>[[Basil Williams (historian)|Basil Williams]], ''Carteret and Newcastle'' (1943), [https://books.google.com/books?id=S7M8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA48#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 48]</ref> Sunderland's papers were seized, and a letter of thanks addressed to him by the Pretender came to light.<ref name=foda/>
In England, insufficient money had been collected by the Jacobites to provide enough arms to support a rising, leading Mar (writing in March 1722) to comment on hearing this that Goring, "though a honest, stout, man, had not showed himself very fit for things of this kind."<ref name=hop></ref>
Walpole's agents began the search for evidence against the leading suspects of [[Jacobitism]], but they found little. Despite this, Walpole gave orders for several men to be arrested: [[Charles Butler, 1st Earl of Arran|Arran]], [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford (1672–1739)|Strafford]], Orrery, North and Grey, Goring, Atterbury, the Duke of Mar's agent George Kelly, and Christopher Layer. Atterbury, who had long been an opponent of Walpole, was named as a conspirator by Mar and was arrested on 24 August 1722, to be charged with treason.<ref name=foda>[http://www.foda.org.uk/oaths/intro/introduction3.htm#25 Devon and Exeter Oath Rolls, 1723] at foda.org.uk/oaths, accessed 12 June 2013</ref><ref>Alfred James Henderson, ''London and the national government, 1721–1742: a study of city politics and the Walpole administration'' (Duke University Press, 1945), p. 71</ref> He and Orrery were imprisoned in the [[Tower of London]]. On 17 October the [[Habeas Corpus Act 1679|Habeas Corpus Act]] was suspended.<ref>Hywel Williams, ''Cassell's Chronology of World History'' (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2005, {{ISBN|0-304-35730-8}}), p. 298</ref>
Goring, meanwhile, avoided arrest and had fled the country on 23 August; he remained in France until his death in 1731. In his absence, at a trial where he was considered one of the major managers of the plot, his agent stated Goring had attempted to enlist a gang of one thousand [[brandy]] [[smuggling|smugglers]] to assist the projected invasion. This led to some government action against such smuggling.<ref name=hop></ref>
Layer was arrested and lodged with Atterbury in the Tower, his clerks were placed under surveillance, and his wife was arrested and brought to London from [[Dover]]. He was less fortunate than most of the others arrested, as two women agreed to give evidence against him. His case was first heard at the [[Court of King's Bench]] on 31 October 1722, and a trial began on 21 November before the Lord Chief Justice, [[John Pratt (judge)|John Pratt]]. Among compromising papers found in the possession of Elizabeth Mason, a brothel-keeper, was one entitled ''Scheme'', said to be in Layer's hand, which outlined a proposed insurrection. The Court was interested to have evidence that the [[James Francis Edward Stuart|Pretender]] and his wife had acted as godparents to Layer's daughter, when they were represented at a christening in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]] by the proxies Lord North and Grey and the [[James Butler, 2nd Duke of Ormonde|Duchess of Ormonde]].<ref name=dnblayer/> After a trial lasting eighteen hours, the jury unanimously found Layer guilty of [[treason|high treason]]. On 27 November 1722, he was sentenced to be [[hanged, drawn, and quartered]], but execution was several times delayed, in the hope of his giving information against others, which he refused to do. He was eventually executed at [[Tyburn]] on 17 May 1723.<ref name=dnblayer/>
Atterbury's correspondence with the Jacobites in exile which could be found proved to have been so cautious that it was not judged to be enough to lead to his conviction. He was therefore the target of a Pains and Penalties Bill, with the aim of removing him from his church positions, banishing him for life, and forbidding British subjects to communicate with him, by the decision of parliament rather than through prosecution in a court.<ref name=dnb/><ref name=szechi>Daniel Szechi, ''The Jacobites: Britain and Europe, 1688–1788'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=kWr1KaDAxZEC&pg=PR19#v=onepage&q&f=false p. xix]</ref> The evidence offered to parliament consisted chiefly of a [[spaniel]] named Harlequin, a present from the Pretender, and some letters found in a lavatory, leading to suspicions that Atterbury was the victim of a Whig conspiracy.<ref>Irvin Ehrenpreis, ''Swift: vol. III: Dean Swift'' (Routledge, 1983), [https://books.google.com/books?id=RRwOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA139#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 139]</ref> However, in May 1723 the Pains and Penalties Bill aimed at him was approved by the [[House of Commons of Great Britain|Commons]] and by the [[House of Lords|Lords]], where the voting was eighty-three votes for and forty-three against, being finally enacted on 15 May, two days before the execution of Layer. On 18 June, Atterbury went into exile in France.<ref name=dnb/><ref name=szechi/> Orrery remained in the Tower for six months, after which he was given bail. There was insufficient evidence to proceed against him.<ref>Lawrence Berkley Smith, [http://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?did=1&uin=uk.bl.ethos.492677 Charles Boyle, 4th Earl of Orrery, 1674–1731], University of Edinburgh dissertation, 1994</ref>
Among the other conspirators, John Plunkett and George Kelly were also arrested and were punished by being deprived of their estates.<ref>Henderson (1945), p. 72</ref> Lord North and Grey was known to be involved, but those who could have implicated him refused to do so.<ref>Eveline Cruickshanks, 'Lord North, Christopher Layer and the Atterbury Plot: 1720–23', in ''The Jacobite Challenge'' (Edinburgh, 1988), p. 94</ref>
In January 1723, a secret parliamentary committee was established to investigate the Plot, and this reported in March of the same year. The [[Papists Act 1722]] required landowners to take oaths of allegiance by Christmas Day, 1723; those who would not do so were obliged to register their estates and risked forfeiting them.<ref>[http://www.foda.org.uk/oaths/intro/glossary.htm#1723act 1723 Act] at foda.org.uk</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * ''Letters of Francis Atterbury, Bishop of Rochester to the Chevalier de St. George and Some of the Adherents of the House of Stuart'' (London, 1847) * ''The Atterbury Plot'' (eds.), Eveline Cruickshanks & Howard Erskine-Hill, Palgrave Macmillian, 2004''
==External links== * [http://broadsides.law.harvard.edu/keyword_search_frame.php?query=008038363 The last speech and dying words of Christopher Layer, Esq; who was executed at Tyburn, for high-treason, on Friday the 17th of May, 1723] – Harvard Law School, Dying Speeches & Bloody Murders * 'The Trial of Christopher Layer, November 21st 1722,' in T.B. Howell (ed.), ''A Complete Collection of State Trials and Proceedings for High Treason'', 21 Volumes, Vol. XVI (Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London 1816), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Kso0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA93#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 93-322] * 'Proceedings in Parliament against John Plunkett, George Kelly alias Johnson, and Dr. Francis Atterbury, Bishop of Rochester, A.D. 1723,' in T.B. Howell (ed.), ''A Complete Collection of State Trials and Proceedings for High Treason'', 21 Volumes, Vol. XVI (Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme & Brown, London 1816), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Kso0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA323#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 323-696]
[[Category:18th-century coups d'état and coup attempts]] [[Category:1721 in Great Britain]] [[Category:1722 in Great Britain]] [[Category:Attempted coups]] [[Category:Conspiracies]] [[Category:Jacobitism]]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Ottoman Sultan selim III 1789.jpg]] → [[File:Ottoman Sultan Selim III (1789).jpg]] [[c:COM:FR#FR3|Criterion 3]] (obvious error)
revision.text:
{{about|meeting a head of state||Audience (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=December 2011}} [[File:Ottoman Sultan Selim III (1789).jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Audience of the French diplomat le Vicomte d'Andrezel with the Sultan [[Selim III]] on 10 October 1724 in the [[Topkapı Palace]].]] An '''audience''' is a formal meeting that takes place between a [[head of state]] and another person at the invitation of the head of state. Often, the invitation follows a request for a meeting from the other person. Though sometimes used in republics to describe meetings with [[president]]s, the term is more usually associated with [[monarch]]s and [[pope]]s.
==Holy See== In the past, rigid [[dress code]]s had to be followed by those granted a papal audience. Although no longer mandatory, the traditional dress code was quite strict. For a general audience, smart business professional attire (i.e,. a suit and tie or equivalent for ladies) was acceptable. The suit was to be dark, and ladies would ideally not wear slacks anywhere in the Vatican. Private audiences, however, were a much more formal affair. Ladies were to wear a long (well below the knees), black dress, with a matching hat or other head covering and veil. Exceptions were made for [[Rex Catholicissimus|Catholic queens]] who by dispensation could wear white ([[privilège du blanc]]). Gentlemen were to wear a correct [[morning suit]], either black or very dark gray with the traditional striped trousers, patent leather shoes, and [[morning coat|cutaway]]. An ascot or equivalent formal tie would be worn with a gray waistcoat over a white dress shirt with arrow collars. If any part of the audience was to occur outdoors a black top hat would be worn. If the function was entirely indoors then the hat was optional for men. Both gentlemen and ladies were to wear dress gloves. Evening functions were usually [[white tie]].
Formal dress is now normally reserved for diplomatic audiences. In the 1990s, a Roman Catholic priest in Ireland provoked a controversy by claiming that then-[[President of Ireland]], [[Mary Robinson]], had breached protocol by wearing jewellery and by not wearing black nor a [[mantilla]] for an audience with [[Pope John Paul II]]. The Vatican subsequently pointed out that the traditional form of dress worn for papal audiences was no longer obligatory.
Modern popes grant large audiences to crowds in [[Saint Peter's Square|St. Peter's Square]] or the [[Paul VI Audience Hall]].
==United Kingdom== In the [[United Kingdom]], audiences with the [[British monarch]] are usually listed in the [[Court Circular]], which is published daily by the [[broadsheet]] press. The [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] has a weekly audience with [[Elizabeth II]], usually every Wednesday,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/HMTheQueen/DayInTheLife/TheQueensworkingday/Evening.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=11 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307195445/https://www.royal.gov.uk/HMTheQueen/DayInTheLife/TheQueensworkingday/Evening.aspx |archivedate=7 March 2013 }}</ref> during parliamentary time at [[Buckingham Palace]].
==Denmark== In the [[Kingdom of Denmark]], public audiences with the Queen usually take place every other Monday at [[Christiansborg Palace]]. An invitation is not required for the public audiences. Private audiences of the Queen with [[heads of state]], [[heads of government]], parliamentary delegations, leaders of international organisations and military leaders are usually held at the residence palace of the Monarch at [[Amalienborg Palace]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://kongehuset.dk/monarkiet-i-danmark/Offentlig-audiens/audiens| title=Audiens| publisher=kongehuset.dk| accessdate=2012-06-27}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}}
[[Category:State ritual and ceremonies]] [[Category:Meetings]]

revision.text:
'''Campus Antiwar Network''' (CAN) is an [[United States|American]] independent grassroots network of students opposing the [[History of Iraq (2003–2011)|occupation of Iraq]] and [[military recruitment|military recruiters]] in US schools. It was founded prior to the 2003 invasion of [[Iraq]], and claims to be the largest campus-based [[antiwar]] organization in the [[United States]].{{cite web | url=http://www.campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=93&Itemid=52 | title=What is CAN? | work=Campus Antiwar Network website | date=7 September 2005 | accessdate=2006-02-27}} ==History== The Campus Antiwar Network was created on January 17, 2003 by delegates from over 70 colleges and universities at twin conferences at [[George Washington University]] and [[San Francisco State University]].[http://grassrootspeace.org/CANjan1703.html grassrootspeace.org] Its purpose was opposition to the planned invasion of Iraq. Because it is decentralized, CAN's size and impact do not necessarily correlate with its national events and organizations, but the group's history can be tracked roughly by its national conventions. ===First National CAN Convention=== ''Chicago, Illinois—February 22–23, 2003'' CAN's first national conference occurred very soon after its formation, the weekend of February 22–23, in [[Chicago]], and formalized the organization's structure and politics. The 2003 convention occurred during a period of rapid growth of the antiwar movement, just prior to the invasion of Iraq and soon after the [[February 15, 2003 anti-war protest]], the largest in world history. The convention was attended by more than 350 delegates from approximately 100 campus groups. At its 2003 convention, CAN adopted a structure under the principle that it be student owned and operated. The specific directives were:
CAN will remain independent, and is not affiliated with any other organization, though it pledges to work with all forces in the antiwar movement; it is democratic, so that each member campus can elect delegates through their local antiwar student coalitions and each affiliated campus group has an equal voice within CAN; CAN accepts affiliation from every campus or school antiwar organization and respects the right of its member committees to organize independent antiwar actions locally.
CAN adopted its first four Points of Unity: #No war on Iraq, whether backed by the U.S. or the [[United Nations]] #End the UN [[International sanctions|sanctions]] which have killed more than 1 million Iraqis #Oppose the attacks on civil liberties and racist [[scapegoating]] at home #Money for jobs, education, and health care, not war. CAN also decided to call for an April 5 national mobilization in a few major cities following on the heels of the student-labor week of action already being organized from March 31 to April 4.[http://traprockpeace.org/CANmediaalert022503.html grassrootspeace.org] ===Second National CAN Convention=== ''Chicago, Illinois—November 1–2, 2003'' The U.S. antiwar movement lost momentum with the failure of mass protests to prevent the invasion, and the Campus Antiwar Network was affected by the trend. CAN's second convention, on November 1–2, 2003, was attended by approximately 100 members, from 34 different campuses around the country. The primary goals of the activists were to discuss the past six months of work since CAN's creation in January, and to organize future goals as well as further codifying the Points of Unity. An important national action taken from this conference was the resurrection of the "black armband" as a symbol of antiwar unity; a throwback from the [[Opposition to the Vietnam War|Vietnam War]]. The Points of Unity were expanded into the following: #We stand opposed to all US wars of aggression. #We stand opposed to the occupation of Iraq. #We support the right of the Iraqi people to self-determination. #We demand the immediate withdrawal of all troops from Iraq. #We call for the US government to pay reparations to the Iraqi people. #We stand opposed to the oppression of the Palestinian people and the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. #We stand opposed to racist scapegoating and all attacks on civil liberties. #We demand money for education, jobs and health care, not war and occupation! ==="Stop the War in 2004"=== ''New York City, New York—November 13–14, 2004'' Over 100 delegates from 30 schools were in attendance at "Stop the War in 2004," which was focused around recovering from the recent [[United States presidential election, 2004|presidential election]] and the re-election of George W. Bush. The main speaker at the event was [[Mike Hoffman (veteran)|Mike Hoffman]], co-founder of the [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]], who spoke about the Iraqi response to the occupation. CAN decided to increase positive interaction and support with military groups opposing the occupation of Iraq, as well as to organize demonstrations "against George Bush's inauguration."[http://campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=57 Campus Antiwar Network] Although all other Points were proposed to stand as created, the national conference revised the Point of Unity on the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]]:
We stand opposed to the oppression of the Palestinian people and the occupation of Palestinian land, and support the right of Palestinians to self-determination.
==="On the Frontlines"=== ''Berkeley, California—October 22–23, 2005'' With falling approval ratings for President [[George W. Bush]] and the war, the growth of the [[counter-recruitment]] movement, and [[Cindy Sheehan]]'s rise to national prominence, CAN grew significantly over the course of 2005. Its fourth national conference, held October 22–23, 2005, at [[UC Berkeley]], drew over 650 participants, with delegates from 37 schools present to vote on the second, organizational, day.{{cite web | author=Jenks, Charlie | url=http://traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar.html | title=CAN History | work=Traprock Peace Center website | date=24 January 2005 | accessdate=2006-02-27}} The conference, jointly sponsored by the Campus Antiwar Network and Military Out of Our Schools-Bay Area, sought to deepen the growing counter-recruitment movement among students. It decided on several nationally coordinated events for the upcoming year: a day of action in protest of the [[Solomon Amendment]] requiring universities to allow military recruitment on December 6 of that year; a week of action marking the anniversary of the war in Iraq, with student actions planned on campuses and general, off-campus actions on the weekend of March 18–19, 2006; and a day of action on May 4, 2006, the anniversary of the killing of four students at [[Kent State shootings|Kent State]] by National Guardsmen during a protest against the [[Vietnam War]], as well as a memorial for the lesser-known shooting of two [[Jackson State killings|Jackson State]] students on May 14. CAN's call for the student week of action was endorsed by many individuals and organizations including [[Cindy Sheehan]], [[Howard Zinn]], and the [[Progressive Democrats of America]]. CAN's Points of Unity and national structure were unchanged. ==="Students Rising"=== ''Madison, Wisconsin—October 19–21, 2007'' [[File:Can conference 2007.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Activists listen to Camilo Mejía's speech at CAN's fifth national conference in Madison.]] The surge in the antiwar movement in late 2005 did not last through 2006, and over the course of that year the Campus Antiwar Network lost much of its national organization, rebuilding only in the spring of 2007. After a one-year hiatus without a national conference, CAN reconvened over the weekend of October 19–21, 2007, to discuss its Points of Unity and to solidify membership. Over 30 chapters sent representatives, with an estimated 200 activists (both delegates and guests) attending. The main event was speaker [[Camilo Mejía]], who talked about his time in Iraq and his gradual realization of his antiwar feelings. Mejía and [[Liam Madden]], both members of the [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]], were in attendance throughout the conference. CAN revised its Points of Unity into the following Unity Statement:
The Campus Antiwar Network stands for the immediate withdrawal from Iraq of all occupation troops and private contractors. CAN is committed to building a movement based on grassroots, democratic and independent organizing that actively opposes all forms of racism, Islamophobia, sexism and homophobia.[http://campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=195 Campus Antiwar Network]
==Structure== The Campus Antiwar Network is a network of largely independent affiliates which choose their own day-to-day goals and tactics. CAN brings them together, usually only by [[email]] and [[conference call]], to share the lessons of experience, discuss and decide on a view of the present needs of the [[peace movement]], assist each other in defending against threatened disciplinary action or prosecution, and plan coordinated actions on both national and regional levels. Major decisions regarding structure and points of unity are made at CAN's yearly national conference, attended by 2 delegates with voting rights from each chapter, as well as an unlimited number of guests. The organization also has a coordinating committee, elected at each national conference. As of the nation conference in 2007, the national committee has been restructured from previous forms to have five regional representatives and four at-large representatives, with decisions made by majority rule. In the past, the committee has had one representative from each of five regions, five at-large representatives, and two high school representatives. Individual CAN affiliates organize as they choose, although each is asked to select two members to give their contact information to the national coordinating committee. The coordinating committee is responsible for coordinating actions voted on at the national conference.{{cite web | author=Karpoff, Josh | url=http://traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar_network/index.php/2005/10/28/minutes-2005-campus-antiwar-network-national-conference-oct-22-23-2005-berkeley-ca/ | title=CAN Conference 2005 Minutes | work=Campus Antiwar Network blog | date=28 October 2005 | accessdate=2006-02-27 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060712160010/http://www.traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar_network/index.php/2005/10/28/minutes-2005-campus-antiwar-network-national-conference-oct-22-23-2005-berkeley-ca/ | archivedate=12 July 2006 | df= }} ==Politics== CAN's only formal political consensus stems from its Points of Unity, or Unity Statement, selected at the national conference. CAN periodically updates its Points of Unity based on the current state of the war and antiwar movement. CAN is first and foremost a group opposed to the [[war in Iraq]]. However, besides calling for immediate withdrawal of all U.S. troops from Iraq, Points of Unity have included opposition to the war in [[Afghanistan]], opposition to [[Israel]]'s [[occupation of Palestine]], and other views. Although some opinions are more controversial than others, CAN strives to reflect the viewpoints of its democratic and varying membership. CAN affiliates are involved in actions around these issues to varying degrees, and individual members may or may not agree with all points; CAN chapters are welcome to choose their own political positions and affiliations beyond the Points of Unity that all chapters follow. Throughout its history, CAN has focused on grassroots organizing, and put [[counter-recruitment|opposition to US military recruitment]] and building relationships with antiwar U.S. veterans and soldiers at the center of its strategy to end the war. CAN does not take official positions on elections of any kind, believing that such choices should be based on individual preferences. However, CAN actively encourages members and chapters to become as informed on elections as possible, and local chapters often incorporate political discussions into their own meetings. After [[Hurricane Katrina]], by decision of its coordinating committee, CAN adopted the slogan "Relief Not War!" for the September 25, 2005 protest in Washington, DC. This issue was connected to the war, for CAN members, by the repressive military nature of the relief efforts as well as by the diversion of resources abroad. In February 2006, CAN issued a statement on the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|Danish cartoons controversy]], condemning "racism in any form, as recently displayed in the publication of a series of anti-Islamic cartoons," which it argued "are helping to promulgate state violence against Muslims and Arabs -- including the occupation of Iraq." The statement also attacked the [[Dubai Ports World controversy]], describing widespread bipartisan opposition to allowing a company from the United Arab Emirates to take ownership of some U.S. port operations as "blatantly racist."{{cite web | url=http://www.campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=144&Itemid=2 | title=CAN condemns racism against Muslims and Arabs | work=Campus Antiwar Network website | date=28 February 2006 | accessdate=2006-03-19}} Anti-racism points of unity were integrated into the Unity Statement in 2007. ==Tactics== Historically, the Campus Antiwar Network has used a variety of [[tactic (method)|tactics]]: *[[Demonstration (people)|National demonstrations]]: CAN helped to mobilize students for the national February 15, 2003 antiwar protest demonstrations prior to the invasion of Iraq, and more recently marched with a contingent estimated by organizers at two thousand people at the [[September 24, 2005 anti-war protest]] in Washington, DC. It has also called its own national actions. For example, CAN called for and organized a day of action on December 6, 2005, the date that the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] heard [[Forum for Academic and Institutional Rights|FAIR]] v. [[Donald Rumsfeld|Rumsfeld]], a case deciding the constitutionality of the [[Solomon Amendment]]'s provision denying federal funding to colleges that ban military recruiters. The action consisted of protests at recruiting stations across the country.{{cite journal | author=Schenwar, Maya | url=http://www.commondreams.org/views05/1205-32.htm | title=Counter-Recruitment Day Sweeps US Colleges | journal=[[Common Dreams]] | date=5 December 2005 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051214202332/http://www.commondreams.org/views05/1205-32.htm | archivedate=14 December 2005 | df= }} *[[Referendum]]s: CAN helped write and campaign for the [[Proposition I/College Not Combat|"College Not Combat"]] ballot measure passed by residents of [[San Francisco]] on November 2, 2005, described by proponents as a statement that voters "want it to be city policy to oppose military recruiters’ access to public schools and to consider funding scholarships for education and training that could provide an alternative to military service."{{cite web | url=http://www.collegenotcombat.org/ | title=We Won! | work=College Not Combat website | accessdate=2006-02-27}} *Direct [[aid]]: CAN sent caravans to [[New Orleans]] from places such as [[New York (city)|New York]] and [[Chicago]], after Hurricane Katrina. These brought supplies and volunteers to work with local [[Louisiana]] activists, such as [[Malik Rahim]], towards hurricane relief. The New York students kept a journal of their activities called [http://www.campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=97&Itemid=2 "This is solidarity, not charity"]. *Talks, debates, and speaking tours: In Fall of 2003, the Campus Antiwar Network (CAN) and [[Muslim Students' Association]] (MSA) organized a national speaking tour titled "Speaking Truth to Empire." The tour's purpose was to reorganize the student antiwar movement. Featured speakers included [[Noam Chomsky]], [[Rania Masri]], [[Howard Zinn]], as well as military families and veterans.[http://campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=20 Campus Antiwar Network - Berkeley] Following this, CAN and MSA co-sponsored another tour called "Eyewitness to Empire," which featured CAN member, [[Khury-Petersen Smith]], who traveled to Iraq and spent a week in Baghdad during January 2004.[http://campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=44 Campus Antiwar Network - San Francisco State University] *[[Petitions]], letters, and phone calls to school and government officials. *Creative performances of various kinds, involving, for example, [[spoken word]] poetry and [[hip hop music|hip hop]] artists. *International collaboration. CAN sent delegates to the [[London]] International Peace Conference on December 10, 2005. CAN also put on a panel discussion called "Fighting the Empire From Within," featuring CAN activists involved in military "counter-recruitment," war resister Pablo Paredes, and others, at the 2006 [[World Social Forum]] in [[Caracas]], Venezuela.{{cite web | author=Jenks, Charlie | url=http://traprockpeace.org/london_peace_10dec05.html | title=London International Peace Conference | work=Traprock Peace Center website | date=10 December 2005 | accessdate=2006-02-27}} More recently, CAN has nationally decided to get involved with the Iraqi Student Project,http://www.iraqistudentproject.org/ a humanitarian aid project which seeks to bring Iraqi college students to America for higher education. *Blockades and [[Direct Action]]: CAN claimed sector 6 in the [[RNC Welcoming Committee]] map at the St Paul [[Republican National Convention]] in 2008, where they attempted to block Republican delegates from reaching the excel center in an attempt to prevent a quorum.{{cite web |url=http://www.nornc.org/2008/07/15/sector-6-can/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726063017/http://www.nornc.org/2008/07/15/sector-6-can/ |archivedate=2012-07-26 |df= }} Six members were arrested at the RNC, one was charged with conspiracy to riot, felony. ===Student walkouts=== Campus Antiwar Network chapters have long used local walkouts as a tactic to demonstrate against the militarization of campus and collusion with war related activities while galvanizing public opinion on campus, unifying CAN groups with other progressive groups, and recruiting new members. The network is able to utilize the internet and conference calls to rapidly create walk outs, although most of the largest walkouts are on specific anniversaries or important dates. Several walkouts occurred immediately after the US invasion of Iraq including a large one at San Francisco State University.[http://www.traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar_1.html Student Activism - Campus Antiwar Network] In 2005, a walkout took place at the [[University of Wisconsin in Madison]].[http://badgerherald.com/news/2005/11/03/antiwar_groups_stage.php The Badger Herald - Anti-war groups stage walk-out] Over 100 students left class, demonstrated, and then marched past the Army Recruitment Center at University Square.[http://badgerherald.com/news/2005/04/15/demonstrators_walk_o.php The Badger Herald - Demonstrators ‘Walk Out’ against occupation of Iraq] In 2007, large walkouts occurred as a result of the efforts of CAN groups. On February 15, the fourth anniversary of the largest antiwar demonstrations in history, walkouts occurred at 17 different schools including [[Columbia University]].http://media.www.columbiaspectator.com/media/storage/paper865/news/2007/02/15/News/Walkout.Set.For.Today-2722194.shtml{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Columbia walkout achieved campus-wide support including a petition signed by forty professors and an endorsement by three campus unions. Three hundred students participated in the antiwar activities that followed. On March 20, 2007, the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, nearly 80 schools answered calls from Campus Antiwar Network and [[Students for a Democratic Society (2006 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]] to walk out of class in protest of the war. Hundreds of students from schools across the country walked out against the war and demonstrated in highly visible locations. At [[Rutgers University]] in New Brunswick New Jersey, 400 students walked out of class, blocked a marine recruiting station, and took over an interstate highway.[http://www.traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar_network/index.php/2007/05/09/the-great-rutgers-walkout/ Campus Antiwar Network Consolidated Blog » Blog Archive » The Great Rutgers Walkout] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814190033/http://www.traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar_network/index.php/2007/05/09/the-great-rutgers-walkout/ |date=2007-08-14 }} CAN views walkouts as a good way to get students involved with the antiwar movement for the first time. As many students fight against the apathy that is the generalization of their generation,{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/27/AR2007012701215.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Student Protesters, Fighting Image of Apathy, Call for a Cohesive Movement | first=Megan | last=Greenwell | date=January 28, 2007 | accessdate=April 28, 2010}} viewing fellow collegiates in action is important to continue growing the movement. ==Repression== A number of people involved with the Campus Antiwar Network have faced legal or disciplinary consequences of various kinds for their antiwar activism. These people have been the centers of nationwide defense campaigns on the part of CAN, which argues that their cases prove the threat counter-recruitment poses to the powers that be. *In March 2004, at [[City College of New York]], four people were arrested at a counter-recruitment protest (after twice, at earlier protests, forcing recruiters off campus) for allegedly assaulting campus security, though they claim that the reverse was the case. One, Hadas Thier, was banned from campus and suspended. Charges have since been dropped.{{cite journal | url=http://www.lrp-cofi.org/PR/ccnyPR75.html | title=CCNY Cracks Down on Anti-Military Protesters | journal=[[League for the Revolutionary Party|Proletarian Revolution]] | issue=75 | year=Fall 2005}} *In March 2005, three student activists, [[Katrina Yeaw]], Michael Hoffman and Pardis Esmaeili, from [[San Francisco State University]] received letters stating that the administration had received a complaint from the Chief of Public Safety for their involvement in a counter-recruitment protest on campus and that each student must meet individually with Judicial Affairs. The following week the six student organizations that endorsed the demonstration received letters stating that disciplinary proceedings were going forward against them. The charges against four of the groups and three student activists were eventually dropped but the university went forward with hearing against the [[International Socialist Organization]] and Students Against War, convicting both groups of all charges against them in absentia.{{cite web |url=http://www.counterpunch.org/yeaw06092005.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081229133134/http://www.counterpunch.org/yeaw06092005.html |archivedate=2008-12-29 |df= }} *Charles Peterson at [[Holyoke Community College]] was pepper sprayed, banned from campus, and threatened with expulsion after allegedly assaulting a campus security officer while protesting military recruiters; he claims that he merely grabbed back a sign the officer took from a fellow protester. Charges have since been dropped.{{cite journal | author=Grim, Ryan | url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20051031/protest_and_pushback_on_campus | title=Protest and Pushback on Campus | journal=[[The Nation]] | date=31 October 2005 | subscription=yes}} *Tariq Khan, a student at [[George Mason University]] and [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] veteran, was arrested for standing near recruiters with a sign saying "Recruiters Tell Lies" taped to his shirt on the charge of trespassing and disorderly conduct. Khan is a Pakistani-American; he reported that one arresting officer told him, "You people are the most violent people in the world." Charges have since been dropped. *[https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/_/id/8957250 Dave Airhart], a student at [[Kent State]] and a [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] veteran of Iraq and Afghanistan, was fined by city police and threatened with expulsion after hanging a banner with an antiwar message on a climbing wall set up on campus by military recruiters. Charges have since been dropped.{{cite web | author="Maduin" | url=http://www.dailykos.com/tag/David%20Airhart | title=Kent State Drops Charges Against David Airhart | work=[[Daily Kos]] | accessdate=2006-02-27 | date=17 November 2005}} *Seven students at [[Hampton University]] were punished for participating in an unauthorized protest and "proselytizing" during a walkout on November 2, 2005. The students were initially summoned for an administrative hearing on November 21 to present a case against their expulsion, with three days notice, but it was then postponed to December 2, and finally the school decided only to impose community service.{{cite web | author=Robinson, John | url=http://www.campusantiwar.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=134 | title=Students Not Expelled! - But Fight Not Over | work=Campus Antiwar Network website | accessdate=2006-02-27 | date=3 December 2005}} ==="Credible Threat" to National Security=== On April 5, 2005, Santa Cruz students and members of the Campus Antiwar Network led a major demonstration on the campus of [[UC Santa Cruz]]. According to the [[San Francisco Chronicle]], "about a dozen protesters entered a career fair in a campus building and surrounded a table where military recruiters sat, preventing other students from talking with them. [And] more than 300 people demonstrated outside. In the jostling that ensued, a career- center staffer was slightly injured." The protest had significant results, according to Kristin Anderson, a member of the Campus Antiwar Network. She believes that counter recruitment "has gotten popular because it gives students something concrete they can do" and students are able to make connections if they see their classmates being tempted by recruiters. UC Santa Cruz antiwar group, "Members of Students Against War" rallied outside of the "San Francisco's Civic Center" wearing T-shirts reading, "Credible Threat." This was done to mock the "Pentagon spymasters' assessment of the group's activities."Garofoli. Joe. "Santa Cruz students nurture anti-war role / Pentagon listing has made them 'credible'." The San Francisco Chronicle: Mar 15, 2006. pg. A.1 ==See also== *[[List of anti-war organizations]] *[[List of peace activists]] ==References== {{reflist}} Most photos are from the [http://www.traprockpeace.org/ Traprock Peace Center website]. ==External links== *[http://www.campusantiwar.net/ Campus Antiwar Network]: the official webpage. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060207204031/http://afromerica.com/avenues/channels/maneuvers/problackmoves/antiwarnetwork.php Afroamerica]: a brief profile of CAN. *[http://www.traprockpeace.org/campus_antiwar.html Traprock Peace Center]: an extensive photo-history of CAN *[http://www.objector.org/recruiting.html Military Out of Our Schools]: a San Francisco Bay Area-based organization with which CAN has cooperated in several campaigns. *[http://www.ivaw.org Iraq Veterans Against the War]: Giving a voice to the large number of active duty service people and veterans who are against this war, but are under various pressures to remain silent. CAN has worked extensively with them in the past. *[http://www.nationalyounglords.com A Latino Resource] ===Media=== *[https://www.wsj.com/public/article/SB113382997643614626-_DBwiX7i01TLGkGnUaDCnzoJATw_20061205.html Law Schools, Military Battle Over Recruiting]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}: a [[Wall Street Journal]] article on December 6 protests. *[https://www.rollingstone.com/special/8952417 Mavericks, Renegades, and Troublemakers 2005]: CAN and Iraq war veteran/Kent State student Dave Airhart in [[Rolling Stone]] magazine. *[http://www.thenation.com/doc/20051031/protest_and_pushback_on_campus Protest and Pushback on Campus]: [[The Nation]] article on counter-recruitment and repression, October 31, 2005. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051230232818/http://www.counterpunch.org/their03152005.html Counter-Recruitment is Gaining Strength]: [[CounterPunch]] on repression against CAN students in spring 2005. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050925204546/http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=7609 Student Protest Prevents CIA Recruiting Event at NYU]: [[Z Magazine]] article on protest organized by a CAN-affiliate at NYU that led to a CIA recruiting event's cancellation. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060518120325/http://www.zmag.org/content/showarticle.cfm?ItemID=8104 A New Battleground on Campuses]: a CAN member's article on campus polarization that summarizes some of CAN's counter-recruitment organizing in spring 2005. *[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4546739/ What happened to the antiwar movement?]: [[MSNBC]] article on CAN and other anti-occupation activism a year after the 2003 invasion of Iraq. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051229145142/http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=05%2F03%2F18%2F1450222 Campus Resistance]: early report on CAN's {{short description|American conservative commentator and political activist.}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{pp-semi|small=yes}} {{Infobox person | name = Candace Owens | image = Candace Owens by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg | caption = Owens in 2018 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1989|4|29}} | birth_place = [[Stamford, Connecticut]], U.S. | residence = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = Public speaker, blogger | employer = [[Turning Point USA]] | years_active = | television = | spouse = | children = }} '''Candace Owens''' (born April 29, 1989)<ref>{{cite episode |title=Joe Rogan Experience #1125 – Candace Owens |episode-link= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Nnzpy5GRak&t=1m43s |access-date=June 24, 2018 |series=PowerfulJRE |series-link= |first= |last= |network= |station= |date=May 31, 2018 |season= |series-no= |number= |minutes= |time=1:43 |transcript= |transcript-url= |quote=I just turned 29. |language=}}</ref> is an [[American conservative]] commentator and political activist. She is known for her pro-[[Donald Trump|Trump]] stance and her criticism of [[Black Lives Matter]] and of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":8">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2018/04/23/a-step-by-step-guide-to-how-kanye-west-became-a-hero-of-the-pro-trump-internet/|title=Analysis {{!}} 'The Mob Can't Make Me Not Love Him': How Kanye West Joined the Pro-Trump Internet|last=Ohlheiser|first=Abby|date=April 25, 2018|work=The Washington Post|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|date=April 23, 2018|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2018/04/kanye-west-shania-twain-candace-owens-donald-trump/558683/|title=What Kanye West and Shania Twain See in Donald Trump|last=Kornhaber|first=Spencer|work=The Atlantic|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> She is the Director of Communications at the conservative advocacy group [[Turning Point USA]].
==Early life and education== She is [[African-American]] and grew up in [[Stamford, Connecticut]],<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|date=June 23, 2018|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/youtube-tested-trump-approved-how-candace-owens-suddenly-became-loudest-n885166|title=YouTube Tested, Trump Approved: How Candace Owens Suddenly Became the Loudest Voice on the Far Right|work=NBC News|access-date=June 29, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Owens is a graduate of [[Stamford High School (Stamford, Connecticut)|Stamford High School]].<ref name="CTPostVictim">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctpost.com/local/article/We-were-children-I-wasn-t-the-only-6872580.php|title=We Were Children. I Wasn't the Only Victim|last=Cuda|first=Amanda|authorlink=|date=March 5, 2016|work=[[Connecticut Post]]|accessdate=|quote=}}</ref> She was raised by her grandparents after her parents divorced.<ref name=":12" />
In 2007, while a senior in high school, Owens received threatening racist phone calls that were traced to a car in which the 14-year-old son of then mayor [[Dannel Malloy]] was present. Owens' family sued the Stamford Board of Education in federal court alleging that the city did not protect her rights, resulting in a $37,500 settlement.<ref name="CTPostVictim" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Racist-threats-case-filed-by-Stamford-High-107476.php|newspaper=Danbury News Times|title=Racist Threats Case Filed by Stamford High Student Settled for $37,500|date=January 23, 2008}}</ref>
Owens was pursuing an undergraduate degree in journalism at the [[University of Rhode Island]] but left school after her junior year.<ref name=":12" /> Afterwards, she worked for [[Vogue (magazine)|''Vogue'']] magazine.<ref name="CTPostVictim" /> In 2012, she took a job as an administrative assistant for a private equity firm.<ref name="CTPostVictim" />
== Career ==
=== Privacy violation, Gamergate and political transformation === Owens launched SocialAutopsy.com in 2016, a website she said would expose [[Cyberbullying|bullies on the Internet]] by tracking their digital footprint.<ref name=":12" /><ref name=CTPostVictim /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/meet-kanye-wests-toxic-far-right-consigliere|title=Meet Candace Owens, Kanye West's Toxic Far-Right Consigliere|last=Zimmerman|first=Amy|date=May 9, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en}}</ref> The proposed site would have solicited users to take screenshots of offensive posts and send them to the website, where they would be categorized by the user's name.<ref name=CTPostVictim /> She used [[crowdfunded|crowdfunding]] on [[Kickstarter]] for the website. The proposal was immediately controversial, drawing criticism that she was de-anonymizing ([[doxing]]) Internet users and violating their privacy.<ref name=":12" /><ref name="NYMAG"/> According to ''[[The Daily Dot]]'', "People from all sides of the anti-harassment debate were quick to criticize the database, calling it a public-shaming list that would encourage [[doxing]] and retaliatory harassment."<ref name="DailyDot">[https://www.dailydot.com/irl/online-bullying-database-doxing-kickstarter-suspended/ Controversial Bully Shaming Database Loses Kickstarter but Will Launch Anyway]. [[The Daily Dot]], April 15, 2016</ref> Both conservatives and progressives involved in the [[Gamergate controversy]] condemned the website.<ref name=":12" />
In response, people began posting Owens' private details online.<ref name=":12" /> Owens blamed, without evidence, the doxing on progressives involved in the Gamergate controversy.<ref name=":12" /><ref name="NYMAG">{{Cite web |last1=Singal |first1=Jesse |title=The Strange Tale of Social Autopsy, the Anti-Harassment Start-up That Descended into Gamergate Trutherism |work=[[New York (magazine)|Select All]] |date=April 18, 2018 |url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2016/04/how-social-autopsy-fell-for-gamergate-trutherism.html |language=en |accessdate=August 26, 2018 }}</ref> After this, she earned the support of conservatives involved in the Gamergate controversy, including right-wing political commentators and Trump supporters [[Milo Yiannopoulos]] and [[Mike Cernovich]].<ref name=":12" /> After this, Owens became a conservative, saying in 2017, "I became a conservative overnight ... I realized that liberals were actually the racists. Liberals were actually the trolls ... Social Autopsy is why I'm conservative".<ref name=":12" />
Kickstarter suspended funding for Social Autopsy, and the website was never created.<ref name="NYMAG" />
=== Media and conservative activism === In 2015, Owens founded the website Degree180.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":12" /> The website frequently posted anti-conservative and anti-Trump content, including mockery of his penis size.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|date=May 15, 2018|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/josephbernstein/the-newest-star-of-the-trump-movement-ran-a-trump-bashing|title=The Newest Star of the Trump Movement Ran a Trump-Bashing Publication – Less Than Two Years Ago|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=May 16, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/387883-conservative-activist-praised-by-trump-once-ran-online-publication|title=Activist Praised by Trump Once Ran Online Publication That Mocked Him: Report|last=Sanchez|first=Luis|date=May 15, 2018|work=TheHill|access-date=May 16, 2018|language=en}}</ref> In a 2015 column that Owens wrote for the site she criticized conservative Republicans, writing about the "bat-shit-crazy antics of the Republican Tea Party", adding, "The good news is, they will eventually die off (peacefully in their sleep, we hope), and then we can get right on with the OBVIOUS social change that needs to happen, IMMEDIATELY."<ref name=":12"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearlife.com/daily-brief/candace-owens-used-run-liberal-leaning-website/|title=Degree180: Candace Owens' Defunct Liberal-Leaning Website|date=May 16, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=October 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.degree180.com/jokes-on-us-the-republican-tea-party-is-being-led-by-the-mad-hatter/|title=News Update: The Republican Tea Party Is Led by the Mad Hatter|last1=Owens|first1=Candace|date=October 4, 2015|publisher=Degree180|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170823111144/http://www.degree180.com/jokes-on-us-the-republican-tea-party-is-being-led-by-the-mad-hatter/|archive-date=August 13, 2017|accessdate=January 7, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":2"/><ref name=":12" /> When ''Buzzfeed News'' in May 2018 reported on the anti-Trump content on Degree180, Owens described the Buzzfeed reporter as a "despicable creature" and alleged that Buzzfeed had threatened the former writers of Degree180 (an allegation that Buzzfeed denied).<ref name=":0" />
By 2017, Owens had become prominent in conservative circles for her pro-Trump commentary and for criticizing liberal rhetoric regarding structural racism, systemic inequality, and identity politics.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":3" /> In 2017, she began posting politically themed videos to YouTube.<ref name=":0" /> She launched Red Pill Black, a website and [[YouTube]] channel that promotes [[black conservatism in the United States]].<ref name="SalonStar">{{Cite web|url=https://www.salon.com/2017/09/25/candace-owens-red-pill-black-youtube/|title=Candace Owens of Red Pill Black, the Toxic Right's Newest African-American Star|last=Watkins|first=D|authorlink=|date=September 25, 2017|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|accessdate=|quote=}}</ref><ref name="FoxRedPill">[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/09/13/liberals-sick-alt-left-are-taking-red-pill.html Fox News: "Liberals Sick of the Alt-Left Are Taking 'the Red Pill'" By Elizabeth Ames] September 13, 2017</ref>
On November 21, 2017, at the [[Make America Great Again|MAGA]] Rally and Expo in [[Rockford, Illinois]], [[Turning Point USA]] founder [[Charlie Kirk (activist)|Charlie Kirk]] announced her appointment as the organization's director of urban engagement.<ref name="MAGATPIllinois">{{Cite web|url=https://www.turningpoint.news/maga-illinois-charlie-kirk/|archive-date=May 3, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503192025/https://www.turningpoint.news/maga-illinois-charlie-kirk/|title=In Liberal Illinois, TPUSA's Charlie Kirk and Other Speakers Strike a Chord with Conservative Crowds – Turning Point USA News|date=May 3, 2018|access-date=June 13, 2018}}</ref> Turning Point's hiring of Owens occurred in the wake of allegations of racism at Turning Point.<ref name=":0" />
In April 2018, [[Kanye West]] tweeted "I love the way Candace Owens thinks."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/04/21/kanye-west-far-right-candace-owens|title=Kanye West Tweets that He Likes the Way Far-Right Personality Candace Owens 'Thinks'|work=[[The FADER]]|access-date=April 22, 2018|language=en}}</ref> The tweet was met with derision among some of West's fans.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thewrap.com/kanye-west-black-lives-candace-owens/|title=Kanye West Applauds Black Lives Matter Critic; Many Fans Revolt: 'This Is So Disturbing'|date=April 21, 2018|work=[[TheWrap]]|access-date=April 22, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> In May 2018, President [[Donald Trump]] stated that Owens "is having a big impact on politics in our Country. She represents an ever expanding group of very smart 'thinkers,' and it is wonderful to watch and hear the dialogue going on...so good for our Country!"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/386857-trump-praises-candace-owens-as-a-very-smart-thinker|title=Trump Praises Conservative Activist Candace Owens as a 'Very Smart Thinker'|last=Shelbourne|first=Mallory|date=May 9, 2018|work=[[TheHill]]|access-date=May 9, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
Owens has appeared on fringe conspiracy websites, such as [[InfoWars]].<ref name=":12" /><ref name=":2"/><ref name=":8" /> In 2018, she guest hosted on Fox News.<ref name=":12" /> After finding mainstream success, Owens distanced herself from the far-right conspiracy websites, although she refused to criticize them.<ref name=":12" />
In May 2018, Owens suggested that "something bio-chemically happens" to women who do not marry or have children, and she linked to the Twitter handles of [[Sarah Silverman]], [[Chelsea Handler]] and [[Kathy Griffin]], saying that they were "evidentiary support" of this theory.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/the-wrap/article/Candace-Owens-Gets-Gently-Dunked-on-by-Sarah-12922930.php|title=Candace Owens Gets Gently Dunked on by Sarah Silverman over 'Women Who Don’t Marry' Tweet|work=SFGate|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/sarah-silverman-responds-conservatives-suggestion-single-women-without-children-bio-chemically-affected-132926216.html?guccounter=1|title=Sarah Silverman Responds to Conservative's Suggestion That Single Women Without Children Are 'Bio-Chemically' Affected|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Silverman responded, saying "It seems to me that by tweeting this, you would like to maybe make us feel badly. I'd say this is evidenced by ur effort to use our twitter handles so we would see. My heart breaks for you, Candy. I hope you find happiness in whatever form that takes."<ref name=":1" /> Owens responded, accusing Silverman of supporting terrorists and crime gangs.<ref name=":1" />
==Political views== ===Ideology=== ''The Guardian'' has described Owens as "ultra-conservative",<ref name=":5">{{Cite|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/may/09/trump-candace-owens-very-smart-thinker|title=Trump Praises Controversial Pundit Candace Owens as a 'Very Smart Thinker'|last=Lartey|first=Jamiles|date=May 9, 2018|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref> and ''New York'' magazine and the ''Columbia Journalism Review'' have described her as "right-wing".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2018/04/why-kanye-west-endorsed-candace-owens.html|title=Kanye West, Galaxy Brain|last=Feldman|first=Brian|newspaper=New York Magazine|date=April 23, 2018 |access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cjr.org/the_media_today/chozick-hillary-farrow.php|title=Politics Meet Publishing in Vooks by Chozick, Farrow, Goldberg, Tapper|work=Columbia Journalism Review|first1=Pete |last1=Vernon |date=April 24, 2018|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en}}</ref> ''The Daily Beast'' has called her views "far-right" and the ''Pacific Standard'' called her a member of the "[[alt-right]]",<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://psmag.com/social-justice/why-is-kanye-west-sounding-like-the-alt-right|title=Why Is Kanye West Sounding Like the Alt-Right?|publisher=Pacific Standard|date=April 27, 2018|first1=Hanif |last1=Abdurraqib}}</ref> though she has rejected both terms.<ref>{{cite tweet |user=realcandaceo |number=987767992493707264 |date=April 21, 2018 |title=Far right? Allow me to clarify: I believe the black community can do it without hand-outs. }}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=realcandaceo |number=994299770192760832 |date=May 9, 2018 |title=I’m not opposed to it. Send me an e-mail.}}</ref>
=== 2017 onward support of Donald Trump === In 2017, Owens began describing herself as a conservative Trump supporter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://atlantablackstar.com/2018/05/19/trick-candace-owens-headed-anti-trump-publication-less-two-years-ago-report-reveals/|title=Is This a Trick? Candace Owens Headed an Anti-Trump Publication Less Than Two Years Ago, Report Reveals|first=Tanasia|last=Kenney|date=May 19, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=October 30, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":12"/>
Owens has since characterized Trump as the "savior" of Western civilization.<ref name=":3" /> She has argued that Trump has neither engaged in rhetoric that is harmful to African Americans nor proposed policies that would harm African Americans.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":2" />
=== Race relations === Owens is known for her criticism of [[Black Lives Matter]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/candace-owens/|title=Who Is Candace Owens, Kanye West's Favorite New Thinker?|date=May 14, 2018|work=The Daily Dot|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/27/arts/music/kanye-west-trump-conservatives.html|title=In Kanye West, the Right Sees Truth-Telling and a Rare A-List Ally|date=April 27, 2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/identities/2018/5/2/17311286/kanye-west-slavery-comments-tmz|title=The Ignorance of Kanye West|work=Vox|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref> She has described Black Lives Matter protesters as "a bunch of whiny toddlers, pretending to be oppressed for attention."<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/04/22/kanye-wests-embrace-of-a-black-trump-supporter-not-well-received/|title=Analysis {{!}} Kanye West's Embrace of a Black Trump Supporter Not Well-Received|last=Scott|first=Eugene|date=April 22, 2018|work=The Washington Post|access-date=May 18, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Owens has argued that African Americans have a "victim mentality" and often refers to the Democratic Party as a "plantation".<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /> She has argued that the American left "like black people to be government-dependent".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/finance/work/leaders/i-love-the-way-candace-owens-thinks-kanye-west-praises-conservative-activist-on-twitter/news-story/3a8b33f86ea6ff3f78e701ee0f504159|title='I Love the Way Candace Owens Thinks'|work=NewsComAu|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref> Owens has argued that black people have been brainwashed to vote for Democrats.<ref name=":8" /> She has argued that police violence against black people is not about racism.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":9" /> According to ''The Guardian'' and ''The Daily Beast'', Owens has referred to police killings of black people as a trivial matter to African Americans.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":2" /> She has characterized abortion as a tool for "the extermination' of black babies."<ref name=":12"/>
After the 2017 [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], Owens said that concern over rising white nationalism was “stupid”.<ref name=":12" />
=== Climate change === Owens rejects the [[scientific opinion on climate change|scientific consensus on climate change]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stanforddaily.com/2018/05/29/tpusa-representatives-talk-identity-politics-trump-and-data/|title=TPUSA Representatives Talk Identity Politics, Trump and Empirical Evidence|date=May 30, 2018|work=The Stanford Daily|access-date=June 17, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":12" /> She has called climate change a lie used to "extract dollars from Americans."<ref name=":12" />
=== Me Too movement === Owens described the [[Me Too movement]] – which is an international movement against [[sexual harassment]] and [[assault]] – as "stupid" and said that she "hated" the movement.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/conservatives-turn-on-candace-owens-kanye-wests-favorite-republican|title=Conservatives Turn on Candace Owens, Kanye West's Favorite Republican|last=Sommer|first=Will|date=June 13, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=June 13, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/us/politics/women-conservative-trump.html|title=At Conservative Women's Conference, a Safe Space for Trumpism|last=Herndon|first=Astead W.|access-date=June 17, 2018|language=en}}</ref> Owens wrote that it was premised on the idea that "women are stupid, weak & inconsequential."<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":10" /> She has repeatedly criticized feminism.<ref name="The Lost Boys The young men of the alt-right could define American politics for a generation">{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/12/brotherhood-of-losers/544158/|title=The Lost Boys: The Young Men of the Alt-Right Could Define American Politics for a Generation|last=Nagle|first=Angela|date=December 2017|work=The Atlantic|quote=Candace Owens, a popular young black conservative also known as Red Pill Black, has mastered new media platforms, but in service of advocating for something closer to a traditional strain of conservatism: She’s critical of the press, feminism, and open borders, but supports gay marriage}}</ref>
=== Dispute with Mollie Tibbetts' family === In August 2018, Owens had a dispute with a cousin of [[Killing of Mollie Tibbetts|Mollie Tibbetts]]. Mollie was murdered, allegedly by Cristhian Bahena Rivera, an illegal alien working under a false name who was arrested and charged with Mollie's murder and who subsequently led investigators of the Poweshiek County Sheriff's Office to Mollie's body.<ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/turning-point-usa-iowa-charlie-kirk-candace-owens-mollie-tibbetts-event-2018-8?r=UK&IR=T|title=Members of a Conservative Student Group Apologize to Charlie Kirk, Candace Owens over 'Misunderstanding' on Mollie Tibbetts Event|work=Business Insider|access-date=August 27, 2018|language=en}}</ref> Tibbetts' cousin criticized Owens saying she exploited Tibbetts' death and used Tibbetts' death as "political propaganda."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisisinsider.com/mollie-tibbetts-death-republicans-pushing-immigration-2018-8|title=Mollie Tibbetts' Twitter Shows She Was a Strong Feminist and Clinton Supporter. Some Republicans Are Using Her Death to Push for Trump's Border Wall.|work=Insider|access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/08/22/stop-being-snake-distant-cousin-mollie-tibbetts-tells-partisans-not-politicize-her-death/|title=Mollie Tibbetts Relative Tells 'Despicable' Partisans Not to Politicize Her Distant Cousin's Death|website=The Washington Post|language=en|access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref> Owens responded, describing the cousin's criticism as a "strange" attack on Trump supporters.<ref name=":14">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/tpusas-university-of-iowa-board-quits-in-protest-of-exploiting-mollie-tibbetts-death|title=TPUSA Members Quit in Protest of 'Exploiting' Mollie Tibbetts' Death|last=Bixby|first=Scott|date=August 24, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=August 27, 2018|language=en}}</ref> After the dispute, a local chapter of Turning Point USA criticized Owens for "public harassment" towards a member of Tibbetts' family.<ref name=":14" />
=== Promoting conspiracy theories about October 2018 bombing attempts === In October 2018, during the [[October 2018 United States mail bombing attempts|bombing attempts targeting prominent Democrats]], Owens promoted the conspiracy theory that the bomb mailings were sent by leftists.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/clinton-obama-cnn-bombs-democrats-conservatives-rush-limbaugh-2018-10|title=Prominent conservative activists and talking heads are promoting a conspiracy theory that Democrats sent explosive devices to Clinton, Obama, and Soros|last=Relman|first=Eliza|date=October 24, 2018|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=October 30, 2018}}</ref> After authorities arrested a 56-year-old suspect who is a registered Republican and Trump supporter on October 26, Owens deleted her comments without explanation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/candace-owens-deletes-bomber-false-flag-tweet/|title=Candace Owens under fire for deleting bomb threat conspiracy tweet|last=Gilmour|first=David|date=October 26, 2018|publisher=The Daily Dot|accessdate=October 30, 2018}}</ref>
===Blexit movement=== In October 2018, Owens launched the Blexit movement, a campaign to encourage [[African Americans]] to abandon the Democratic Party and register as Republicans. The term Blexit—a [[portmanteau]] of “[[Black people|black]]" and "exit”—mimics [[Brexit]], the word used to describe the United Kingdom's [[withdrawal from the European Union]]. On the launch, Owens said that her "dear friend and fellow superhero [[Kanye West]]" designed merchandise for the movement, but the following day, West denied being the designer and disavowed the effort, saying "I never wanted any association with Blexit" and "I've been used to spread messages I don't believe in."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/in-the-know/413953-kanye-west-denies-he-designed-blexit-shirts-ive-been-used|title=Kanye West denies he designed 'Blexit' shirts: 'I've been used'|last=Anapol|first=Avery|date=October 30, 2018|work=TheHill|access-date=October 30, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/kanye-west-candace-owens-blexit-and-politics-749784/|title=Kanye West Distances Himself From Alt-Right Provocateur Candace Owens|last=Klinkenberg|first=Brendan|date=October 30, 2018|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=October 30, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/97400/what-is-blexit |title=What is Blexit? |publisher=The Week UK |date=October 29, 2018 |accessdate=October 31, 2018}}</ref> Shortly after the launch, ''The Daily Beast'' found that approximately 16 percent of the total tweets using the #blexit hashtag were from Twitter accounts associated with the promotion of Russian disinformation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-propaganda-veterans-push-candace-owens-blexit-campaign|title=Exclusive: Russian Propaganda Veterans Push Candace Owens’ ‘Blexit’|last=Sommer|first=Kevin Poulsen{{!}}Will|date=November 3, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=November 5, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
On October 31, 2018, Owens was sent a trademark infringement cease and desist letter by an attorney for Blexit, a Minneapolis-based non-profit founded in 2016 that is developing a black-led credit union.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/pro-trump-activists-blame-charlie-kirk-and-candace-owens-for-losing-kanye-west/|title=Pro-Trump Activists Blame Charlie Kirk and Candace Owens for Losing Kanye West|last1=Sommer|first1=Will|date=October 31, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=October 31, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-propaganda-veterans-push-candace-owens-blexit-campaign|title=Russian Propaganda Veterans Push Candace Owens’ ‘Blexit’ Campaign|last1=Poulsen|first1=Kevin|date=November 2, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=November 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/blexitmn/status/1058005822402449408|title=BLEXIT on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=November 1, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Pavia, Will (June 9, 2018), "[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/magazine/the-times-magazine/interview-with-candace-owens-trump-kanye-west-and-me-wwlxn8q7r Interview with Candace Owens]", ''[[The Times]]''.
==External links== {{Commons cat|Candace Owens}} * {{YouTube|c=UCL0u5uz7KZ9q-pe-VC8TY-w|Red Pill Black}} * {{IMDb name|9219306|Candace Owens}}

revision.text:
'''The Catholic Campaign for America''' (CCA) is a Roman Catholic activist organization founded in 1989 by Thomas V. Wykes, Jr., "who wanted to address the moral crisis in America with a Catholic response".
In 1991, Wykes gathered together several notable Catholic leaders in [[Washington, D.C.]], who constituted the CCA's first Board. They included [[William Bennett]], [[Robert Bork|Mary Ellen Bork]], Bishop [[René Henry Gracida]], and the now-deceased [[Hugh Carey]] (former Governor of New York). According to the ''[[National Catholic Register]]'', the CCA was initiated to ''"bring a politically powerful and distinctively Catholic voice to the U.S. political scene"''.
Wykes is also the founding president of [http://www.springtimeoffaith.org Springtime of Faith Foundation], headquartered in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].
==Motto== "The Gospel of Jesus Christ is not a private opinion, a remote spiritual ideal, or a mere program for spiritual growth. The Gospel is the power to transform the world."
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927202809/http://www.catholicherald.com/articles/00articles/gforsyth.htm Catholic Herald] * [http://www.zenit.org/article-27609?l=english ZENIT] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120419134656/http://www.dioceseofnashville.com/a-springfest2011.htm Roman Catholic Diocese of Nashville website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Catholic Campaign for America}} [[Category:Roman Catholic activists]] [[Category:Catholic Church in the United States]]
{{poli-org-stub}}
